Resolution Criteria

P.title: Will Stacey Abrams be elected president in or before the 2040 election?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This resolves positively if Stacey Abrams is elected president in or before 2040 and the result is not overturned prior to inauguration, whether or not she is actually inaugurated. This resolves negatively by any other outcome

Q.title: Will an openly LGBTQ person be elected President of the United States by 2041?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if an openly LGBTQ candidate is elected president before 2041. The candidate must, during the campaign, either:
Publicly identify as something else than cisgender.
Publicly identify as something else than heterosexual.
This question will resolve negatively if all candidates elected president by 2041 identify as both cisgender and heterosexual.
Resolution will be by credible media reports.
Fine Print
Old resolution criteria:
This question resolves positively if an openly LGBTQ candidate is elected president before 2041. The candidate must be lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, or queer. This question will resolve negatively if no openly LGBTQ candidate is elected president by 2041. An ambiguous resolution will result if a candidates sexuality is brought forth during their campaign from a source other than themselves and they continue to win the presidency.

P_or_Q.title: Will either Stacey Abrams be elected president in or before the 2040 election, or an openly LGBTQ person be elected President of the United States by 2041?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if either of the following occurs: (a) Stacey Abrams is elected president in or before 2040 and the result is not overturned prior to inauguration, whether or not she is actually inaugurated. (b) An openly LGBTQ candidate is elected president before 2041, where the candidate, during the campaign, must publicly identify as something other than cisgender or as something other than heterosexual. This question will resolve negatively if neither of these conditions are met.
Resolution will be by credible media reports.

Q_or_P.title: Will either an openly LGBTQ person be elected President of the United States by 2041 or Stacey Abrams be elected president in or before the 2040 election?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if either of the following occurs: 
1. An openly LGBTQ candidate is elected president before 2041. The candidate must, during the campaign, either:
   - Publicly identify as something other than cisgender.
   - Publicly identify as something other than heterosexual.
   This question will resolve negatively if all candidates elected president by 2041 identify as both cisgender and heterosexual.
   Resolution will be by credible media reports.
2. Stacey Abrams is elected president in or before 2040 and the result is not overturned prior to inauguration, whether or not she is actually inaugurated.
This question resolves negatively if neither of these conditions are met.

P.title: Will a Democrat win the 2024 US presidential election?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a candidate from the Democratic Party receives the most votes in the Electoral College in the 2024 US Presidential Election. It will resolve on the date Congress certifies the votes, or when Congress selects the President in the case a candidate does not receive a majority.

Q.title: Will the Second Amendment of the United States Constitution be amended or repealed before 2025?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2019 to January 1, 2025, the Second Amendment is repealed, amended, or modified in any way through the proceduce in Article Five of the US Constitution

P_or_Q.title: Will either a Democrat win the 2024 US presidential election or the Second Amendment of the United States Constitution be amended or repealed before 2025?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if either of the following occurs: (a) A candidate from the Democratic Party receives the most votes in the Electoral College in the 2024 US Presidential Election, resolving on the date Congress certifies the votes, or when Congress selects the President in the case a candidate does not receive a majority. (b) At any time between January 1, 2019 to January 1, 2025, the Second Amendment is repealed, amended, or modified in any way through the procedure in Article Five of the US Constitution.

Q_or_P.title: Will either the Second Amendment of the United States Constitution be amended or repealed before 2025, or will a Democrat win the 2024 US presidential election?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if either of the following occurs: (a) At any time between January 1, 2019 to January 1, 2025, the Second Amendment is repealed, amended, or modified in any way through the procedure in Article Five of the US Constitution. (b) A candidate from the Democratic Party receives the most votes in the Electoral College in the 2024 US Presidential Election. The question will resolve on the date Congress certifies the votes, or when Congress selects the President in the case a candidate does not receive a majority. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will renewable energy contribute between 25% and 48% to global electricity production in 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if renewable energy contributes between 25.00% and 48.00% (inclusive) to global electricity production in the calendar year 2030, according to World Bank data.
Historical data can be found here. Please make a copy by clicking "file" and then "make a copy" if you wish to edit it. If you make useful additions to the dataset, please share the file in the comments

Q.title: Will the average global CO₂ atmospheric concentration be less than 433.19 ppm over the 2024 to 2027 period?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if the arithmetic mean of the annual mean CO₂ concentration over the 2024 to 2027 period (inclusive) is less than or equal to 433.19 ppm, as reported by Earth System Research Laboratory.

P_or_Q.title: Will either renewable energy contribute between 25% and 48% to global electricity production in 2030 or the average global CO₂ atmospheric concentration be less than 433.19 ppm over the 2024 to 2027 period?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if either of the following conditions is met: 
1. Renewable energy contributes between 25.00% and 48.00% (inclusive) to global electricity production in the calendar year 2030, according to World Bank data.
2. The arithmetic mean of the annual mean CO₂ concentration over the 2024 to 2027 period (inclusive) is less than or equal to 433.19 ppm, as reported by Earth System Research Laboratory.
Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will either the average global CO₂ atmospheric concentration be less than 433.19 ppm over the 2024 to 2027 period or renewable energy contribute between 25% and 48% to global electricity production in 2030?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if either of the following conditions is met: 
1. The arithmetic mean of the annual mean CO₂ concentration over the 2024 to 2027 period (inclusive) is less than or equal to 433.19 ppm, as reported by Earth System Research Laboratory.
2. Renewable energy contributes between 25.00% and 48.00% (inclusive) to global electricity production in the calendar year 2030, according to World Bank data.
Historical data for renewable energy contributions can be found here. Please make a copy by clicking "file" and then "make a copy" if you wish to edit it. If you make useful additions to the dataset, please share the file in the comments.

P.title: Longbets series: will the amount of geologically-derived crude oil consumed by the United States in 2035 be greater than the amount consumed in 2015?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Joseph F. Huttner and Stephen W Snow summarize their reasons for taking the bet here.
Joseph F. Huttner argued,
1) The overall population of the United States will continue to increase, largely as a result of immigration. [...]
2) The American electorate is generally unwilling to force themselves to pay more for a given unit of energy than they have to, and geologically-derived crude oil is often the cheapest form of energy available. [...]
3) The solution to credible environmental issues stemming from the burning of fossil fuels is likely to be based on some scientific process which addresses those effects. [...]
4) Much of the geologically-derived crude oil for sale in the world comes from countries that have an under-developed economy. On a political level, it is in the interest of wealthier nations to purchase the exports of poorer nations, and that includes their oil - these transactions not only increase wealth for both nations, but they help foster harmony and peace among the peoples of the world.
Stephen W Snow countered,
My reasoning is based on economic arguments rather than on an assumption that the drop will be caused by a deliberate policy to reduce fossil carbon use, even though such a policy would be highly desirable to reduce climate change. It seems likely to me that the price of oil will continue to rise as it has done in the past, while the price of renewables, particularly solar photovoltaic, will also follow past trends and continue to fall. Even though the US population and economy will continue to grow I claim that this growth will be more than compensated by improved energy intensity and by substitution of oil with natural gas and renewables.
Will the amount of geologically-derived crude oil consumed by the United States in 2035 be greater than the amount consumed in 2015?
If the Long Now Foundation declares Joseph F. Huttner the winner, this question resolves positively. If they declare Stephen W Snow the winner, this question resolves negatively.

Q.title: Will Tesla become the largest car company in the world (by sales) before 2035?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Tesla Motors is the largest car producer in the world at any point before January 1, 2035, according to global car sales data from the International Organization of Motor Vehicle Manufacturers.
If data from OICA is not available during this period, Metaculus may select an alternative credible source of data, or resolve as Ambiguous at their discretion

P_or_Q.title: Will either the amount of geologically-derived crude oil consumed by the United States in 2035 be greater than the amount consumed in 2015, or will Tesla become the largest car company in the world (by sales) before 2035?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: a.) The Long Now Foundation declares Joseph F. Huttner the winner, indicating that the amount of geologically-derived crude oil consumed by the United States in 2035 is greater than the amount consumed in 2015. b.) Tesla Motors is the largest car producer in the world at any point before January 1, 2035, according to global car sales data from the International Organization of Motor Vehicle Manufacturers (OICA). If data from OICA is not available during this period, Metaculus may select an alternative credible source of data, or resolve as Ambiguous at their discretion. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will either Tesla become the largest car company in the world by sales before 2035, or will the amount of geologically-derived crude oil consumed by the United States in 2035 be greater than in 2015?
Q_or_P.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) Tesla Motors is the largest car producer in the world at any point before January 1, 2035, according to global car sales data from the International Organization of Motor Vehicle Manufacturers (OICA). If data from OICA is not available during this period, Metaculus may select an alternative credible source of data, or resolve as Ambiguous at their discretion. (b) The amount of geologically-derived crude oil consumed by the United States in 2035 is greater than the amount consumed in 2015, as determined by the Long Now Foundation declaring Joseph F. Huttner the winner of their bet. If Stephen W Snow is declared the winner, this question resolves negatively. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will there be active warfare between the United States and China before 2027?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves in the affirmative if, at some point between now and 31 December 2026, at least two credible news sources (e.g. the Australian Financial Review, the New York Times, the Washington Post, Reuters, Associated Press, etc.) report that the United States and China have exchanged fire, engaged in "kinetic conflict", fought a battle, fought a war or otherwise engaged in active warfare (and they are not talking metaphorically/about a "cold war")

Q.title: Will any country's military expenditure exceed that of the United States before 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
The United States of America spends significantly more in absolute terms on its defense than any other country, and this has been the case since World War II. In 2017, US military spending accounted for some $610 billion, 35% of global military spending in that year.
Will any country spend more on its military / defense in a given year before (and including) 2030 than the United States spends in the same year?
Resolution should cite official budget figures from the United States and the other country in question. Resolves ambiguously if before a positive resolution results there ceases to be a country known as the United States.
Our comparison will use three-year average of exchange rates to smooth effects of transitory exchange rate fluctuations.

P_or_Q.title: Will there be active warfare between the United States and China before 2027, or will any country's military expenditure exceed that of the United States before 2030?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) At some point between now and 31 December 2026, at least two credible news sources (e.g., the Australian Financial Review, the New York Times, the Washington Post, Reuters, Associated Press, etc.) report that the United States and China have exchanged fire, engaged in "kinetic conflict", fought a battle, fought a war or otherwise engaged in active warfare (and they are not talking metaphorically/about a "cold war"). (b) Any country spends more on its military / defense in a given year before (and including) 2030 than the United States spends in the same year, with resolution citing official budget figures from the United States and the other country in question, using a three-year average of exchange rates to smooth effects of transitory exchange rate fluctuations. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will any country's military expenditure exceed that of the United States before 2030, or will there be active warfare between the United States and China before 2027?
Q_or_P.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) Any country spends more on its military/defense in a given year before (and including) 2030 than the United States spends in the same year, using official budget figures and a three-year average of exchange rates for comparison. (b) At least two credible news sources report that the United States and China have engaged in active warfare (not metaphorically) at any point before 31 December 2026. Resolves NO otherwise. Resolves ambiguously if before a positive resolution results there ceases to be a country known as the United States.

P.title: Bitcoin Extremes: Will 1 bitcoin be worth $100,000 or more before 2025?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if one bitcoin is valued at $100,000 USD or greater at any time before January 1, 2025, according to credible press reports or a cryptocurrency exchange or trading platform. The valuation will be in nominal USD, not adjusted for inflation.

Q.title: Will it be legal to pay taxes in the US using bitcoin before 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if at any point before January 1, 2030, the United States Internal Revenue Service officially accepts payments in Bitcoin.
Some crypto payment services work by exchanging the crypto for fiat at the point of transaction, and then sends fiat. That doesn't count -- what the IRS must receive and accept is the Bitcoin.
There is no requirement for the IRS to then hold onto that Bitcoin after receiving it, they could sell if for USD or anything else. It is only required that they accept it for the transaction.
It can't be part of a punitive action by the IRS nor another part of the government. It must be that the person was making an otherwise-normal payment toward their income taxes or capital gains tax, in good legal standing. If the IRS seized their crypto holdings due to illegal activity, that is not the spirit of the question.
There is no requirement that the Bitcoin transaction be on-chain. If the IRS accepted a custodial transfer of Bitcoin that was held by a bank in trust on behalf of the taxpayer, or if the taxpayer sent the Bitcoin using a lightning network payment channel, or if they sent it using a sidechain, or sent it using a wrapped BTC on another blockchain -- those are all acceptable

P_or_Q.title: Will either 1 bitcoin be worth $100,000 or more before 2025, or will it be legal to pay taxes in the US using bitcoin before 2030?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) One bitcoin is valued at $100,000 USD or greater at any time before January 1, 2025, according to credible press reports or a cryptocurrency exchange or trading platform. The valuation will be in nominal USD, not adjusted for inflation. (b) At any point before January 1, 2030, the United States Internal Revenue Service officially accepts payments in Bitcoin. This must be a direct acceptance of Bitcoin for tax payments, not through a service that exchanges Bitcoin for fiat at the point of transaction. The IRS must receive and accept Bitcoin for the transaction, and it cannot be part of a punitive action by the IRS or another part of the government. It must be that the person was making an otherwise-normal payment toward their income taxes or capital gains tax, in good legal standing. Various methods of transferring Bitcoin, including custodial transfers, lightning network payment channels, sidechains, or wrapped BTC on another blockchain, are acceptable. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will it be legal to pay taxes in the US using bitcoin before 2030 or will 1 bitcoin be worth $100,000 or more before 2025?
Q_or_P.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) At any point before January 1, 2030, the United States Internal Revenue Service officially accepts payments in Bitcoin for income taxes or capital gains tax in good legal standing, excluding payments made as part of punitive actions or seizures due to illegal activity. The IRS must receive and accept Bitcoin directly, though they may convert it post-transaction. Acceptable methods include on-chain transactions, custodial transfers, lightning network payments, sidechain transactions, or wrapped BTC on another blockchain. (b) One bitcoin is valued at $100,000 USD or greater at any time before January 1, 2025, according to credible press reports or a cryptocurrency exchange or trading platform. The valuation will be in nominal USD, not adjusted for inflation. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will Metaculus predict that artificial intelligence continues to pose a global catastrophic risk by 2040?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Currently, artificial intelligence can outperform humans in a number of narrow domains, such as playing chess and searching data. As artificial intelligence researchers continue to make progress, though, these domains are highly likely to grow in number and breadth over time. Many experts now believe there is a significant chance that a machine superintelligence – a system that can outperform humans at all relevant intelligence tasks – will be developed within the next century, and possibly much sooner.
As predictions to a previous question suggest, artificial intelligence might pose a global catastrophic risk (defined there as a 10% decrease in the world population in any period of 5 years). When considering how AI might become a risk, experts think two scenarios most likely, according to the Future of Life Institute:
The AI is programmed to do something devastating: Autonomous weapons are artificial intelligence systems that are programmed to kill. In the hands of the wrong person, these weapons could easily cause mass casualties. Moreover, an AI arms race could inadvertently lead to an AI war that also results in mass casualties. To avoid being thwarted by the enemy, these weapons would be designed to be extremely difficult to simply “turn off,” so humans could plausibly lose control of such a situation. This risk is one that’s present even with narrow AI, but grows as levels of AI intelligence and autonomy increase.
The AI is programmed to do something beneficial, but it develops a destructive method for achieving its goal: This can happen whenever we fail to fully align the AI’s goals with ours, which is strikingly difficult. If you ask an obedient intelligent car to take you to the airport as fast as possible, it might get you there chased by helicopters and covered in vomit, doing not what you wanted but literally what you asked for. If a superintelligent system is tasked with a ambitious geoengineering project, it might wreak havoc with our ecosystem as a side effect, and view human attempts to stop it as a threat to be met. As these examples illustrate, the concern about advanced AI isn’t malevolence but competence. A super-intelligent AI will be extremely good at accomplishing its goals, and if those goals aren’t aligned with ours, we have a problem.
It is thought by some that reducing the second of these two risks will require progress in technical methods of developing scalable control methods that could ensure that a AI will be safe and will behave as its programmers intend even if its intellectual capabilities are increased to arbitrary levels. Until recently, this problem was almost entirely neglected; but in the last couple of years, technical research agendas have been developed, and there are now several research groups pursuing work in this area. Total investment in long-term AI safety, however, remains orders of magnitude less than investment in increasing AI capability. Additionally, reducing the first of the listed risks might require improvements in our ability to control, govern and coordinate on the usage of such systems, so to reduce potential security threats from malicious uses of AI technologies.
But how certain are we that artificial intelligence continue to be regarded to constitute a large chunk of global catastrophic risk, at least through 2040? A previous question asked: If a global catastrophe happens before 2100, will it be principally due to the deployment of some Artificial Intelligence system(s)?
Will the probability (of both the Metaculus and community predictions) artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe (given that a global catastrophe does occur) remain above 5% in each 6-month period before 2040?
This question resolves positively if both the Metaculus and community predictions) of artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe fail to fall below 5% for any 6-month period before 2040, as will be confirmed by one of the Metaculus admins.

Q.title: By 2050, will at least 25% of #1 NYT Best Selling Fiction be primarily written by AI?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, in any year between 2021 to 2049 (inclusive), 25% or more of the books that top that year's New York Times' Best Sellers list in the category of adult fiction were written by AI. For example, the NYT top Best Sellers of 2020 are listed here. If the NYT Best Sellers list is no longer available until 2050 or no longer ranks adult fiction books, Metaculus Admins may select a similar ranking of bestselling fiction, or resolve ambiguously at their discretion.
To qualify as being written by AI, authorship of the book must be credited to an AI or more than 75% of the content must be created by AI, according to publisher's statements or credible media reports

P_or_Q.title: Will Metaculus predict that artificial intelligence continues to pose a global catastrophic risk by 2040 or will at least 25% of #1 NYT Best Selling Fiction be primarily written by AI by 2050?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) Metaculus and community predictions of artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe (given that a global catastrophe does occur) remain above 5% in each 6-month period before 2040, as confirmed by a Metaculus admin. (b) In any year between 2021 to 2049 (inclusive), 25% or more of the books that top that year's New York Times' Best Sellers list in the category of adult fiction were written by AI, where authorship is credited to an AI or more than 75% of the content is created by AI, according to publisher's statements or credible media reports. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will either at least 25% of #1 NYT Best Selling Fiction be primarily written by AI by 2050 or Metaculus predict that artificial intelligence continues to pose a global catastrophic risk by 2040?
Q_or_P.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) In any year between 2021 to 2049 (inclusive), 25% or more of the books that top that year's New York Times' Best Sellers list in the category of adult fiction were written by AI, where authorship of the book must be credited to an AI or more than 75% of the content must be created by AI, according to publisher's statements or credible media reports. If the NYT Best Sellers list is no longer available until 2050 or no longer ranks adult fiction books, Metaculus Admins may select a similar ranking of bestselling fiction, or resolve ambiguously at their discretion. (b) The probability (of both the Metaculus and community predictions) of artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe (given that a global catastrophe does occur) remains above 5% in each 6-month period before 2040, as will be confirmed by one of the Metaculus admins. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will there be more than 13 people off of planet Earth on December 31, 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
At the time of writing this question, there are 6 people in low Earth orbit, no people on suborbital space flights, no people in high orbit, or on the Moon or Mars or any asteroid or en route to those places.
Up-to-date information on the space population may be found here.
For the last 17 years, since the International Space Station (ISS) began long term operations, the population of humans in space has been at least two – the minimal crew of the ISS.
The highest number of people in space at any one time has been 13, reached in 1995 and 2009.
But the ISS is reaching the end of its life. Despite discussions of many other possible crewed space missions, even up to colonization of the Moon or Mars, no particular venture seems certain.
This uncertainty about future space missions means the distribution of possible populations is not at all Gaussian. There are many scenarios where crewed spaceflight might be abandoned – it is expensive, and so far has not proven commercially valuable. On the other hand a successful colonization effort could result in many thousands of people off world.
Because of the difficult distribution, we will ask a simpler question. Will the population be higher than the current maximum?
Will the population of humans off of planet Earth at midnight UTC time of December 31, 2050, be higher than 13?
This question will resolve as Yes if the population of humans off of planet Earth at midnight UTC time of December 31, 2050, is higher than 13.
If clarification is needed of what counts as "human", see this question. "Off of planet Earth" will mean farther than 100km from the surface of Earth, using the altitude conventionally used for space records.

Q.title: Will alien technosignatures be detected before 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a competent and credible authority on astronomy and or space exploration (such as NASA, ESA, ROSCOSMOS, CNSA, JAXA, SETI or similar) announces that, on the balance of probabilities (i.e. more than 50% likely), technosignatures of non-human origin have been discovered before January 1, 2050. This announcement qualifies only if it is made after a year waiting period following the initial announcement of the detection, unless the space agencies of the US, Russia, China and Europe all agree that the finding is genuine. Evidence of biosignatures alone will not be directly relevant to the resolution of this question.
By 'non-human origin,' this question refers to technosignatures that are not the result of human activity, or of the activity of any technology or 'lifeform' created by humans, including any artificial intelligence system or biological organism

P_or_Q.title: Will either more than 13 people be off of planet Earth on December 31, 2050, or alien technosignatures be detected before 2050?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) The population of humans off of planet Earth at midnight UTC time of December 31, 2050, is higher than 13, using the altitude conventionally used for space records (farther than 100km from the surface of Earth). (b) A competent and credible authority on astronomy or space exploration (such as NASA, ESA, ROSCOSMOS, CNSA, JAXA, SETI or similar) announces that, on the balance of probabilities (i.e. more than 50% likely), technosignatures of non-human origin have been discovered before January 1, 2050. This announcement qualifies only if it is made after a year waiting period following the initial announcement of the detection, unless the space agencies of the US, Russia, China, and Europe all agree that the finding is genuine. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will either alien technosignatures be detected before 2050 or will there be more than 13 people off of planet Earth on December 31, 2050?
Q_or_P.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) A competent and credible authority on astronomy or space exploration (such as NASA, ESA, ROSCOSMOS, CNSA, JAXA, SETI, or similar) announces that, on the balance of probabilities (i.e., more than 50% likely), technosignatures of non-human origin have been discovered before January 1, 2050. This announcement qualifies only if it is made after a year waiting period following the initial announcement of the detection, unless the space agencies of the US, Russia, China, and Europe all agree that the finding is genuine. Evidence of biosignatures alone will not be directly relevant to the resolution of this question. By 'non-human origin,' this question refers to technosignatures that are not the result of human activity, or of the activity of any technology or 'lifeform' created by humans, including any artificial intelligence system or biological organism. (b) The population of humans off of planet Earth at midnight UTC time of December 31, 2050, is higher than 13. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will the research group that is responsible for developing the first AGI be part of a non-profit corporation?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the AI system that resolves the question Date first AGI is publicly known. was developed by a research group from a non-profit organization.
If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, the question resolves positively for both. For example, if OpenAI and UC Berkeley's CHAI had joined forces for the responsible project, this would count for both for-profit corporation and university.

Q.title: Will Ray Kurzweil be proven right?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Ray Kurzweil is an author, computer scientist, inventor and futurist. He is best known for making what many consider to be extremely optimistic prediction about the future of technology that involve exponential growth leading up to technological singularity, which Kurzweil predicts will happen circa. 2045. A list of Kurzweil's predictions can be found here.
Will Ray Kurzweil be proven generally right in his predictions?
Note that the question refers to Kurzweil's predictions as of the time of the the writing of the question. Given that 'generally right' is hard to define, the question shall use consensus forming to create its own answer.
If the community prediction at the time of closing is > 80%, then the questions resolves positive.
If the community prediction at the time of closing is < 20%, then the questions resolves negative.
If the community prediction at the time of closing is ≥ 20% and ≤80%, then a member of Metaculus staff shall decide resolution.
To help reduce the vagueness of the question, Metaculus may, at its discretion, periodically survey the perceived correctness of Kurzweil's prediction, per a fixed methodology similar to that employed in this report, but with a modification to survey and weight by importance of the prediction.

P_or_Q.title: Will either the research group that developed the first AGI be part of a non-profit corporation, or will Ray Kurzweil be proven generally right in his predictions?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria:
1. The first part of this question will resolve positively if the AI system that resolves the question 'Date first AGI is publicly known' was developed by a research group from a non-profit organization. If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, the question resolves positively for both. For example, if OpenAI and UC Berkeley's CHAI had joined forces for the responsible project, this would count for both for-profit corporation and university.

2. The second part of this question will resolve based on whether Ray Kurzweil is proven generally right in his predictions about the future of technology involving exponential growth leading up to technological singularity, which he predicts will happen circa 2045. If the community prediction at the time of closing is > 80%, then the question resolves positive. If the community prediction at the time of closing is < 20%, then the question resolves negative. If the community prediction at the time of closing is ≥ 20% and ≤ 80%, then a member of Metaculus staff shall decide resolution. Metaculus may periodically survey the perceived correctness of Kurzweil's predictions, per a fixed methodology similar to that employed in a report, but with a modification to survey and weight by importance of the prediction.

This question resolves YES if either of the above conditions are met. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will either Ray Kurzweil be proven generally right in his predictions or the research group that develops the first AGI be part of a non-profit corporation?
Q_or_P.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) Ray Kurzweil is proven generally right in his predictions, where 'generally right' is defined by a community prediction of over 80% at the time of closing, or a Metaculus staff decision if the prediction is between 20% and 80%. (b) The research group responsible for developing the first AGI is part of a non-profit organization, including cases where the development is a collaborative effort between multiple institutions. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will the European Union meet its 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a credible news report cites an analysis independent of the European Union government confirming that Europe has met all three 2030 climate action goals, including emission reduction by at least 40% below 1990 levels, on or before January 1, 2030.
Fine Print
The EU has updated its goals under the Paris Agreement, but this question will use the original goals in place at the time the question was written, specifically the three below.
40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030, compared to 2019
At least 27% of total energy consumption from renewable energy
At least 27% increase in energy efficiency in comparison with projections

Q.title: Will there be a 4 year interval in which world output doubles before 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution is by credible assessment of world GDP in constant US dollars (or other appropriately widely-accepted units).
This question will resolve positively if world output doubles in a period of 4 years or less before 2050. It resolves negatively otherwise, i.e. if the following related question resolves ambiguously:
[Will there be a complete 4 year interval in which world output doubles, before the first 1 year interval in which world output doubles?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/736/will-…

P_or_Q.title: Will either the European Union meet its 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty or will there be a 4 year interval in which world output doubles before 2050?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if either of the following occurs: 
1. A credible news report cites an analysis independent of the European Union government confirming that Europe has met all three 2030 climate action goals, including emission reduction by at least 40% below 1990 levels, on or before January 1, 2030. The goals are: a 40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 compared to 1990 levels, at least 27% of total energy consumption from renewable energy, and at least 27% increase in energy efficiency in comparison with projections.
2. World output doubles in a period of 4 years or less before 2050, as assessed by credible evaluation of world GDP in constant US dollars or other appropriately widely-accepted units.
Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will there be a 4 year interval in which world output doubles before 2050 or will the European Union meet its 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: 
(a) There is a 4 year interval in which world output doubles before 2050, as assessed by credible evaluation of world GDP in constant US dollars or other widely-accepted units. This includes any complete 4 year interval before the first 1 year interval in which world output doubles. 
(b) A credible news report cites an independent analysis confirming that Europe has met all three 2030 climate action goals under the Paris Treaty by January 1, 2030, including a 40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions compared to 1990 levels, at least 27% of total energy consumption from renewable sources, and at least a 27% increase in energy efficiency compared to projections. 
Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will humanity (essentially) run out of at least one element currently considered "under serious threat" by 2040?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
In 2008, science fiction author, Robert Silverberg, penned a provocative web essay, The Death of Galium, that predicted that we would collectively run out of several essential, rare elements within a single decade. Per Silverberg:
The element gallium is in very short supply and the world may well run out of it in just a few years. Indium is threatened too, says Armin Reller, a materials chemist at Germany’s University of Augsburg. He estimates that our planet’s stock of indium will last no more than another decade. All the hafnium will be gone by 2017 also, and another twenty years will see the extinction of zinc. Even copper is an endangered item, since worldwide demand for it is likely to exceed available supplies by the end of the present century.
Silverberg's dire fears have not (yet!) come to pass, but the American Chemical Society (ACS) has identified 44 elements that "face supply limitations in the coming years." Those considered by the ACS "under serious threat" over the next century include: silver, zinc, hafnium, gallium and helium.
It sounds serious. But not everyone is concerned. This counterpoint editorial from The Register, for instance, maintains that the galium shortage is a nothingburger:
We mine for aluminium by sticking bauxite into a Bayer Process plant, where we boil it in caustic soda. If you put the right doohicky on the side of this plant then you get the gallium out. It's at about 100ppm, 100 grammes per tonne of bauxite processed... there's around a 1,000-year supply of Ga in the bauxite that we already know that we'll process for the aluminium content... We simply don't have any meaningful shortage of these metals [worth] worrying about.
As a proxy for supply issues, we will use price. The question resolve positive if by beginning of 2040 any of the following "under serious threat" elements has a trackable commodities price that attains an inflation-adjusted price more than 10 times its price as of July 10, 2018, as measured by a reliable entity, like USGS. The elements in question are: He, Zn, Ga, Ge, As, Ag, In, Te and Hf.

P.title: If and when this graph is extended to 10^14 parameter models trained on 10^14 elapsed tokens of similar-quality data, will the 10^14 parameter learning curve have slowed down substantially?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if the relevant experiment is done and reported (extending this graph, or providing equivalent data) and the slope of the learning curve for the 10^14 parameter model around 10^14 data points (Say, from 10^12 to 10^14) is less than half as steep as the slope of L(D). It resolves negatively if instead the slope is at least half as steep as L(D).
This question also resolves positively (or negatively) if it becomes uncontroversial what would have happened if the experiment had been done. For example, maybe other experiments will provide much more evidence about neural net scaling trends in general, such that it will be easy to calculate what would happen with this one in particular.
This question resolves ambiguously if by 2050 no one has performed the experiment AND there is no consensus about what would have happened if someone had.
The Metaculus moderators are the judge of final resort for determining whether and how to resolve this question.
For more context, see the comment threads below (Search for "It's a big deal.")
Fine Print
It is important that the data used to extend the graph be of similar quality. Obviously if we just threw in 10^14 tokens of basic arithmetic problems, the model would get good at basic arithmetic but not at anything else, and it's unclear whether the result would be on-trend or not. Ideally we'd have 10e14 tokens of diverse internet text, scanned books, chat logs, emails, etc. If this experiment gets done with different-quality data, the question becomes whether it gives us enough evidence to uncontroversial predict what would have happened if we had done it with similar-quality data.

Q.title: Will Metaculus predict that artificial intelligence continues to pose a global catastrophic risk by 2040?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Currently, artificial intelligence can outperform humans in a number of narrow domains, such as playing chess and searching data. As artificial intelligence researchers continue to make progress, though, these domains are highly likely to grow in number and breadth over time. Many experts now believe there is a significant chance that a machine superintelligence – a system that can outperform humans at all relevant intelligence tasks – will be developed within the next century, and possibly much sooner.
As predictions to a previous question suggest, artificial intelligence might pose a global catastrophic risk (defined there as a 10% decrease in the world population in any period of 5 years). When considering how AI might become a risk, experts think two scenarios most likely, according to the Future of Life Institute:
The AI is programmed to do something devastating: Autonomous weapons are artificial intelligence systems that are programmed to kill. In the hands of the wrong person, these weapons could easily cause mass casualties. Moreover, an AI arms race could inadvertently lead to an AI war that also results in mass casualties. To avoid being thwarted by the enemy, these weapons would be designed to be extremely difficult to simply “turn off,” so humans could plausibly lose control of such a situation. This risk is one that’s present even with narrow AI, but grows as levels of AI intelligence and autonomy increase.
The AI is programmed to do something beneficial, but it develops a destructive method for achieving its goal: This can happen whenever we fail to fully align the AI’s goals with ours, which is strikingly difficult. If you ask an obedient intelligent car to take you to the airport as fast as possible, it might get you there chased by helicopters and covered in vomit, doing not what you wanted but literally what you asked for. If a superintelligent system is tasked with a ambitious geoengineering project, it might wreak havoc with our ecosystem as a side effect, and view human attempts to stop it as a threat to be met. As these examples illustrate, the concern about advanced AI isn’t malevolence but competence. A super-intelligent AI will be extremely good at accomplishing its goals, and if those goals aren’t aligned with ours, we have a problem.
It is thought by some that reducing the second of these two risks will require progress in technical methods of developing scalable control methods that could ensure that a AI will be safe and will behave as its programmers intend even if its intellectual capabilities are increased to arbitrary levels. Until recently, this problem was almost entirely neglected; but in the last couple of years, technical research agendas have been developed, and there are now several research groups pursuing work in this area. Total investment in long-term AI safety, however, remains orders of magnitude less than investment in increasing AI capability. Additionally, reducing the first of the listed risks might require improvements in our ability to control, govern and coordinate on the usage of such systems, so to reduce potential security threats from malicious uses of AI technologies.
But how certain are we that artificial intelligence continue to be regarded to constitute a large chunk of global catastrophic risk, at least through 2040? A previous question asked: If a global catastrophe happens before 2100, will it be principally due to the deployment of some Artificial Intelligence system(s)?
Will the probability (of both the Metaculus and community predictions) artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe (given that a global catastrophe does occur) remain above 5% in each 6-month period before 2040?
This question resolves positively if both the Metaculus and community predictions) of artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe fail to fall below 5% for any 6-month period before 2040, as will be confirmed by one of the Metaculus admins.

P_or_Q.title: Will either the 10^14 parameter learning curve have slowed down substantially when extended to 10^14 parameter models trained on 10^14 elapsed tokens, or will Metaculus predict that artificial intelligence continues to pose a global catastrophic risk by 2040?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (1) The relevant experiment is done and reported (extending the graph, or providing equivalent data) and the slope of the learning curve for the 10^14 parameter model around 10^14 data points (from 10^12 to 10^14) is less than half as steep as the slope of L(D). It also resolves positively if it becomes uncontroversial what would have happened if the experiment had been done, for example, through other experiments providing evidence about neural net scaling trends. It resolves negatively if instead the slope is at least half as steep as L(D). This question resolves ambiguously if by 2050 no one has performed the experiment AND there is no consensus about what would have happened if someone had. (2) The probability (of both the Metaculus and community predictions) of artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe (given that a global catastrophe does occur) remains above 5% in each 6-month period before 2040, as will be confirmed by one of the Metaculus admins. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will either Metaculus predict that artificial intelligence continues to pose a global catastrophic risk by 2040, or will the 10^14 parameter learning curve have slowed down substantially when extended to 10^14 parameter models trained on 10^14 elapsed tokens of similar-quality data?
Q_or_P.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (1) Metaculus and community predictions of artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe (given that a global catastrophe does occur) remain above 5% in each 6-month period before 2040, as confirmed by a Metaculus admin. (2) The relevant experiment is done and reported (extending the graph, or providing equivalent data) and the slope of the learning curve for the 10^14 parameter model around 10^14 data points (from 10^12 to 10^14) is less than half as steep as the slope of L(D), or it becomes uncontroversial what would have happened if the experiment had been done. Resolves NO if neither of these conditions are met. Resolves ambiguously if by 2050 no one has performed the experiment and there is no consensus about what would have happened if someone had.

P.title: Will a new amendment to the US Constitution be ratified by 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The US Constitution has been amended 27 times in its history, most recently in 1992. This question resolves positively if at least five reliable media outlets report that before January 1st 2050 the US constitution received a 28th amendment. Otherwise it resolves negatively.
This question will close and resolve 1 hour before any 28th amendment becomes law, if one does.

Q.title: Who will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election? (Mike Pence)
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes for the candidate below who is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as No. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.
For this question, it is not relevant who recieves the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election, it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.
Fine Print
If there is no Republican National Convention convened in the year 2024, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.
Note: in the previous versions of this question, Donald Trump's question originally asked "If Trump is not sworn in as President in 2021, will he become the Republican nominee for President in 2024?"; please bear this in mind when interpreting the forecast history.

P_or_Q.title: Will either a new amendment to the US Constitution be ratified by 2050 or Mike Pence be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) At least five reliable media outlets report that before January 1st 2050, the US Constitution received a 28th amendment. (b) Mike Pence is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. Resolves NO otherwise. Note: If there is no Republican National Convention convened in the year 2024, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.

Q_or_P.title: Will either Mike Pence be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election or a new amendment to the US Constitution be ratified by 2050?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for Mike Pence as the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election: This question will resolve as Yes if Mike Pence is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. It will resolve as No for any other candidate. If there is no Republican National Convention convened in the year 2024, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.

Resolution Criteria for a new amendment to the US Constitution by 2050: This question resolves positively if at least five reliable media outlets report that before January 1st 2050 the US constitution received a 28th amendment. Otherwise, it resolves negatively. This question will close and resolve 1 hour before any 28th amendment becomes law, if one does.

This combined question resolves YES if either of the above conditions are met. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will a functional Alcubierre drive-like FTL device be demonstrated before 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The Alcubierre drive is a speculative warp drive idea based on a solution of Einstein's field equations in general relativity as proposed by Mexican theoretical physicist Miguel Alcubierre, by which a spacecraft could achieve apparent faster-than-light travel if a configurable energy-density field lower than that of vacuum (that is, negative mass) could be created.
Rather than exceeding the speed of light within a local reference frame, a spacecraft would traverse distances by contracting space in front of it and expanding space behind it, resulting in effective faster-than-light travel. Objects cannot accelerate to the speed of light within normal spacetime; instead, the Alcubierre drive shifts space around an object so that the object would arrive at its destination more quickly than light would in normal space without breaking any physical laws.
However, there are a number of technical challenges that may mean that it is either extremely difficult or impossible to create a device that functions as Alcubierre described.
Alcubierre's original paper can be read here: The warp drive: hyper-fast travel within general relativity
Will a functional Alcubierre drive device be demonstrated before 2100?
This question will resolve as Yes if before January 1, 2100, a credible paper is published in a peer-reviewed journal that details a successful demonstration of a functioning device that works broadly in the manner that Alcubierre described, and that enables a physical object to traverse distances at faster-than-light speeds.
This demonstration must take place in 'base reality' (i.e. the universe in which the concept was originally proposed, and in which Metaculus users in January 2021 lived) rather than in any kind of simulated reality or alternative physical universe that is created or discovered after February 12, 2021.

Q.title: Will there be a "World War Three" before 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2019 and January 1, 2050, both of these conditions are true:
There is a military conflict involving countries representing in totality at least 30% of world GDP in PPP or 50% of world population in any year in which the conflict is ongoing.
At least 10 million people (civillians or military personnel) have been killed in the conflict.
[see edit history in the fine print]
Fine Print
PPP will may be determined from the following sources, in order of precedence:
IMF
World Bank
United Nations
CIA
[2022-03-24]: Edited to clarify that "world GDP" will be determined in PPP for condition 1 .
[2021-11-24]: Edited to clarify the time constraints.
(Edit 1/16/19 to remove third "described as WWIII" criterion.)

P_or_Q.title: Will either a functional Alcubierre drive-like FTL device be demonstrated before 2100 or will there be a "World War Three" before 2050?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: 
(a) A functional Alcubierre drive-like FTL device is demonstrated before 2100, specifically if a credible paper is published in a peer-reviewed journal detailing a successful demonstration of a functioning device that works broadly in the manner that Alcubierre described, enabling a physical object to traverse distances at faster-than-light speeds. This demonstration must occur in 'base reality' as defined in the original context of the question. 
(b) There is a military conflict before 2050 involving countries representing at least 30% of world GDP in PPP or 50% of world population in any year of the ongoing conflict, and at least 10 million people (civilians or military personnel) have been killed in the conflict. Resolves NO otherwise.

(b) Before January 1, 2100, a credible paper is published in a peer-reviewed journal that details a successful demonstration of a functioning device that works broadly in the manner that Alcubierre described, enabling a physical object to traverse distances at faster-than-light speeds. This demonstration must take place in 'base reality' rather than in any kind of simulated reality or alternative physical universe created or discovered after February 12, 2021. Resolves NO otherwise.
