P.title: Will humanity maintain a continuous off-Earth presence until 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Since October 31 2000, the date Soyuz TM-31 lifted off from the Baikonur Cosmodrome carrying the members of Expedition 1, the first long-duration ISS crew, humanity has maintained a permanent off-Earth presence for more than 19 years.
This question asks: Will humanity maintain an off-Earth presence continuously until 1 January 2050?
For a positive resolution, at least one living and conscious biological human must be physically located at some point beyond 100km altitude above Earth's mean sea level at all times continuously until 1 January 2050. This could include persons aboard spacecraft and space stations, as well as persons on any astronomical object other than Earth (e.g. Moon or Mars explorers / settlers).
If the number of living and conscious biological humans off-Earth drops to zero at any time before 1 January 2050, this question resolves negatively. EMs, artificial intelligence systems, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and all other instances of either wholly non-biological or non-conscious humans will not count for the purposes of this question. Humans who are merely sleeping will be considered conscious for the purposes of this question.
However, biological humans with some degree of cybernetic augmentation (brain implants, artificial limbs or organs, etc) will suffice, so long as they could still reproduce with un-augmented humans.

Q.title: Will the USD be the dominant global reserve currency in 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Related Questions on Metaculus:
Will the USD fraction of allocated global foreign exchange currencies be below 50% before the following years?
What will be the United States Dollar's percentage of all currency reserves, as of Q1 2050?
The IMF regularly publishes information on the composition of official global foreign exchange reserves in the aggregated Currency Composition of Foreign Exchange Reserves (COFER). As of Q3 2019, the U.S dollar comprises 61.8% of the total (source).
Several contributing factors are thought to contribute to this state of affairs, including the stability, size, and liquidity of United States Treasury assets, the tying of other currencies to the U.S dollar as part of the Bretton Woods Agreement, and the strength of the U.S economy.
At present, the U.S dollar is considered to be the world's dominant reserve currency. This is considered to diminish the impact of higher U.S trade deficits and allowing it to impose unilateral sanctions. However, it has been speculated that the U.S dollar may be supplanted by the euro or the renminbi, or may diminish in importance.
Will the USD be the dominant global reserve currency in 2050?
Question resolves positively if the most recently released percentage of allocated global foreign currency reserves comprising of the U.S dollar, by year-end 2050, is over 50%. Per moderator discretion, if the IMF has ceased publication of COFER in lieu of a new publication containing the same statistics, the new publication will be used instead.
Question resolves as ambiguous the IMF has not published any statistics for any quarters after Q1 2045, if admins judge that the IMF has ceased to exist.

P_or_Q.title: Will either humanity maintain a continuous off-Earth presence until 2050 or will the USD be the dominant global reserve currency in 2050?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) At least one living and conscious biological human is physically located beyond 100km altitude above Earth's mean sea level at all times continuously until 1 January 2050. This includes persons aboard spacecraft and space stations, as well as persons on any astronomical object other than Earth (e.g., Moon or Mars explorers/settlers). If the number of living and conscious biological humans off-Earth drops to zero at any time before 1 January 2050, this part of the question resolves negatively. EMs, artificial intelligence systems, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and all other instances of either wholly non-biological or non-conscious humans will not count. Humans who are merely sleeping will be considered conscious. Biological humans with some degree of cybernetic augmentation (brain implants, artificial limbs or organs, etc) will suffice, so long as they could still reproduce with un-augmented humans. (b) The most recently released percentage of allocated global foreign currency reserves comprising of the U.S dollar, by year-end 2050, is over 50%. This question resolves as ambiguous if the IMF has not published any statistics for any quarters after Q1 2045, or if admins judge that the IMF has ceased to exist. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will either the USD be the dominant global reserve currency in 2050 or will humanity maintain a continuous off-Earth presence until 2050?
Q_or_P.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) The most recently released percentage of allocated global foreign currency reserves comprising of the U.S dollar, by year-end 2050, is over 50%. This resolution will use the latest available data from the IMF's Currency Composition of Foreign Exchange Reserves (COFER) or its equivalent if COFER is no longer published. If the IMF has not published any statistics for any quarters after Q1 2045, or if admins judge that the IMF has ceased to exist, the question resolves as ambiguous. (b) At least one living and conscious biological human is physically located beyond 100km altitude above Earth's mean sea level at all times continuously until 1 January 2050. This includes persons aboard spacecraft and space stations, as well as persons on any astronomical object other than Earth (e.g., Moon or Mars explorers/settlers). If the number of such humans drops to zero at any time before 1 January 2050, this question resolves negatively. EMs, artificial intelligence systems, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and all other instances of either wholly non-biological or non-conscious humans will not count for the purposes of this question. Humans who are merely sleeping will be considered conscious for the purposes of this question. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will there be at least one fatality from nuclear detonation in North Korea by 2050, if any detonation occurs?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The Nuclear Threat Initiative (NTI) writes that:
"North Korea unilaterally withdrew from the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) in January 2003, is not a party to the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty (CTBT), and has conducted six increasingly sophisticated nuclear tests since 2006. The DPRK is not a party to the Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC), and is believed to possess a large chemical weapons program. Despite being a state party to the Biological and Toxin Weapons Convention (BTWC) and Geneva Protocol, evidence suggests North Korea may maintain an offensive biological weapons program.
In defiance of the international community, which has imposed heavy sanctions on North Korea for its illicit behavior, the country has continued to escalate its WMD activities. In July 2017, North Korea successfully tested its first intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM), and in September 2017 it conducted a test of what it claimed was a thermonuclear weapon."
Tensions between North Korea and other countries have been increased by the country's testing of nuclear weapons and of missiles that may have sufficient range to reach the continental United States. As of 2020, the nuclear arsenal of North Korea was estimated at approximately 30 to 40 warheads, with the sufficient production of fissile material for the creation of an additional 6 to 7 nuclear weapons a year. President Biden has warned Kim Jong-un that if production and testing of nuclear weapons continues, there will be a US "response."
Will there be at least one fatality from an offensive nuclear detonation in North Korea by 2050, if there's an offensive detonation anywhere?
This question will resolve as Yes if at least one fatality occurs in North Korea from an offensive nuclear detonation before January 1, 2050. Neither detonations for testing purposes nor peaceful nuclear explosions will count towards question resolution, even if such detonations cause substantial damage. This question will resolve as No if that does not occur but there's an offensive nuclear detonation somewhere in the world before 2050. This question resolves ambiguously if no nuclear detonation (other than test detonations or peaceful nuclear explosions) occurs anywhere before 2050.
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. If information is unclear, then resolution will be left up to the resolution council or Metaculus admins.

Q.title: Will there be a global thermonuclear war by 2070?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if there is an armed conflict before January 1, 2070 where either of the following conditions are true:
Three countries each detonate at least 10 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory
Two countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.
These conditions are chosen to set aside a two-party regional nuclear war, say between India and Pakistan, or Israel and an adversary, or the UK and France, as disastrous as that would be.
As with many questions with a positive-resolution condition that may preclude being awarded points on Metaculus, predictors are enjoined to predict in good faith, as points will not be awarded until 2070 anyway

P_or_Q.title: Will there be at least one fatality from an offensive nuclear detonation in North Korea by 2050, if there's an offensive detonation anywhere, or will there be a global thermonuclear war by 2070?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) There is at least one fatality in North Korea from an offensive nuclear detonation before January 1, 2050, provided there's an offensive nuclear detonation anywhere in the world. This excludes detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions. (b) There is an armed conflict before January 1, 2070 where either three countries each detonate at least 10 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory, or two countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory. Resolves NO if neither of these conditions are met. The question resolves ambiguously if no nuclear detonation (other than test detonations or peaceful nuclear explosions) occurs anywhere before 2050.

Q_or_P.title: Will there be a global thermonuclear war by 2070 or at least one fatality from nuclear detonation in North Korea by 2050, if any detonation occurs?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolves YES if either of the following conditions are met: 
1. There is an armed conflict before January 1, 2070 where either of these conditions are true: 
a) Three countries each detonate at least 10 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory. 
b) Two countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory. 
2. At least one fatality occurs in North Korea from an offensive nuclear detonation before January 1, 2050, provided there's an offensive nuclear detonation anywhere. This excludes detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions. 
Resolves NO if neither of these conditions are met. The question resolves ambiguously if no nuclear detonation (other than test detonations or peaceful nuclear explosions) occurs anywhere before 2050.

P.title: Ragnarök Question Series: If a global catastrophe occurs, will it be due to either human-made climate change or geoengineering?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
If a global catastrophe happens before 2100, will it be principally due to human-made climate change, or the use of geoengineering as a deliberate large-scale intervention in the Earth’s climate system?
In the headline question to this series, we defined a global catastrophe as a 10% decrease in the world population in any period of 5 years or less. This question resolves ambiguously if no such global catastrophe occurs. On the other hand...
The question results positively if a human-made climate change or geoengineering catastrophe occurs that claims at least 10% in any period of 5 years or less before 2100. This catastrophe must be due to the direct effects of climate change that are generally believed very unlikely in a counterfactual world with little or no global warming but otherwise similar to ours. These include (but are not limited to) floods, extreme weather, the spreading of infectious disease, and the health effects of extreme heat. Finally, the effects due to the effects of the use of geoengineering that has been principally motivated to mitigate climate change risks, also count towards the population decline. Years are here defined as consecutive calendar years.

Q.title: If there's a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030, will this cause >400 million fatalities?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question conditions on there being a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030, using the same specification as in a previous question (except that here the year 2030 is used instead of 2024[1]). That is, the question resolves ambiguously if that condition isn't met. As noted in that previous question, this could be caused either by nuclear conflict or by something else.
The question resolves positively if:
The above condition is met
At least three credible sources state or estimate that, within 5 years of the end of the year in which the first 10% shortfall by 2030 occurs, more than 400 million fatalities were caused by that shortfall.
For example, if the shortfall occurs in 2027, this question is about whether that causes >400m fatalities by the end of 2032.
If a source gives a range as its estimate, the midpoint of that range will be used as its estimate.
See also:
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations cause >1m fatalities within 1 month of the final detonation?
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations cause >100m fatalities within 1 month of the final detonation?
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations cause >1b fatalities within 10 years of the final detonation?
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >1000 detonations cause >4b fatalities within 10 years of the final detonation?
Fine Print
For simplicity, no attempt will be made to second-guess credible sources on what fatalities should be considered to be "caused" by the 10% shortfall. For example, if the 10% shortfall is followed by armed conflict, no attempt will be made to second-guess what credible sources say about whether the fatalities caused by that armed conflict should be considered to be ultimately caused by the 10% shortfall.
[1] The reason for using 2030 rather than 2024 for this question is that the fatalities and discussion of them may occur on a several-year delay from the actual shortfall. It therefore seemed unwise to force this question to resolve by 2024, and hence best to make this part of the long-term rather than calibration tournament.

P_or_Q.title: Will either a global catastrophe occur due to human-made climate change or geoengineering, or will a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030 cause more than 400 million fatalities?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for each part:

1. If a global catastrophe happens before 2100, will it be principally due to human-made climate change, or the use of geoengineering as a deliberate large-scale intervention in the Earth’s climate system? A global catastrophe is defined as a 10% decrease in the world population in any period of 5 years or less. This question resolves ambiguously if no such global catastrophe occurs. The catastrophe must be due to the direct effects of climate change or the effects of the use of geoengineering that has been principally motivated to mitigate climate change risks.

2. This question conditions on there being a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030. It resolves positively if at least three credible sources state or estimate that, within 5 years of the end of the year in which the first 10% shortfall by 2030 occurs, more than 400 million fatalities were caused by that shortfall. For example, if the shortfall occurs in 2027, this question is about whether that causes >400m fatalities by the end of 2032. The question resolves ambiguously if the 10% shortfall condition isn't met.

The combined question resolves YES if either of the above conditions are met, and NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will either a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030 cause >400 million fatalities, or will a global catastrophe by 2100 be due to human-made climate change or geoengineering?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for the agricultural shortfall question:
This question conditions on there being a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030. It resolves ambiguously if that condition isn't met. The question resolves positively if at least three credible sources state or estimate that, within 5 years of the end of the year in which the first 10% shortfall by 2030 occurs, more than 400 million fatalities were caused by that shortfall.

Resolution Criteria for the global catastrophe question:
This question resolves if a global catastrophe, defined as a 10% decrease in the world population in any period of 5 years or less, happens before 2100 and is principally due to human-made climate change or the use of geoengineering as a deliberate large-scale intervention in the Earth’s climate system. The question resolves ambiguously if no such global catastrophe occurs.

The combined question resolves YES if either of the above conditions are met. It resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will there be a "World War Three" before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2019 and January 1, 2050, both of these conditions are true:
There is a military conflict involving countries representing in totality at least 30% of world GDP in PPP or 50% of world population in any year in which the conflict is ongoing.
At least 10 million people (civillians or military personnel) have been killed in the conflict.
[see edit history in the fine print]
Fine Print
PPP will may be determined from the following sources, in order of precedence:
IMF
World Bank
United Nations
CIA
[2022-03-24]: Edited to clarify that "world GDP" will be determined in PPP for condition 1 .
[2021-11-24]: Edited to clarify the time constraints.
(Edit 1/16/19 to remove third "described as WWIII" criterion.)

Q.title: Will a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
For these purposes we define "practical" as an operational high-temperature nuclear fusion reactor that can (a) produce a demonstrated positive energy balance exceeding 100 megawatts for more than one week, and (b) have a sustainable plan for long-term operations (e.g. no critical hard-to-replace components that would be radiation-damaged to inoperability in a matter of days or weeks, etc.) These are chosen to roughly match this question.
This question will resolve as Yes if the first such reactor is built in China, and will resolve as No if the first such reactor is built anywhere else.
If no such reactor is built before January 1, 2050, this question will resolve as Ambiguous

P_or_Q.title: Will either a "World War Three" occur before 2050 or a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) There is a military conflict involving countries representing in totality at least 30% of world GDP in PPP or 50% of world population in any year in which the conflict is ongoing, and at least 10 million people (civilians or military personnel) have been killed in the conflict, anytime between January 1, 2019 and January 1, 2050. (b) The first operational high-temperature nuclear fusion reactor that can produce a demonstrated positive energy balance exceeding 100 megawatts for more than one week and has a sustainable plan for long-term operations is built in China. Resolves NO otherwise. If no such reactor is built before January 1, 2050, this part of the question will resolve as Ambiguous.

Q_or_P.title: Will either a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China or will there be a "World War Three" before 2050?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for practical nuclear fusion reactor:
For these purposes we define "practical" as an operational high-temperature nuclear fusion reactor that can (a) produce a demonstrated positive energy balance exceeding 100 megawatts for more than one week, and (b) have a sustainable plan for long-term operations (e.g. no critical hard-to-replace components that would be radiation-damaged to inoperability in a matter of days or weeks, etc.) These are chosen to roughly match this question.
This part of the question will resolve as Yes if the first such reactor is built in China, and will resolve as No if the first such reactor is built anywhere else.
If no such reactor is built before January 1, 2050, this part of the question will resolve as Ambiguous.

Resolution Criteria for "World War Three":
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2019 and January 1, 2050, both of these conditions are true:
There is a military conflict involving countries representing in totality at least 30% of world GDP in PPP or 50% of world population in any year in which the conflict is ongoing.
At least 10 million people (civillians or military personnel) have been killed in the conflict.

The overall question resolves YES if either of the above conditions are met, and NO otherwise.

P.title: Will there be a 4 year interval in which world output doubles before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution is by credible assessment of world GDP in constant US dollars (or other appropriately widely-accepted units).
This question will resolve positively if world output doubles in a period of 4 years or less before 2050. It resolves negatively otherwise, i.e. if the following related question resolves ambiguously:
[Will there be a complete 4 year interval in which world output doubles, before the first 1 year interval in which world output doubles?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/736/will-…

Q.title: Will humanity maintain a continuous off-Earth presence until 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Since October 31 2000, the date Soyuz TM-31 lifted off from the Baikonur Cosmodrome carrying the members of Expedition 1, the first long-duration ISS crew, humanity has maintained a permanent off-Earth presence for more than 19 years.
This question asks: Will humanity maintain an off-Earth presence continuously until 1 January 2050?
For a positive resolution, at least one living and conscious biological human must be physically located at some point beyond 100km altitude above Earth's mean sea level at all times continuously until 1 January 2050. This could include persons aboard spacecraft and space stations, as well as persons on any astronomical object other than Earth (e.g. Moon or Mars explorers / settlers).
If the number of living and conscious biological humans off-Earth drops to zero at any time before 1 January 2050, this question resolves negatively. EMs, artificial intelligence systems, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and all other instances of either wholly non-biological or non-conscious humans will not count for the purposes of this question. Humans who are merely sleeping will be considered conscious for the purposes of this question.
However, biological humans with some degree of cybernetic augmentation (brain implants, artificial limbs or organs, etc) will suffice, so long as they could still reproduce with un-augmented humans.

P_or_Q.title: Will either world output double within any 4-year interval before 2050, or will humanity maintain a continuous off-Earth presence until 2050?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) World output doubles in a period of 4 years or less before 2050, based on a credible assessment of world GDP in constant US dollars or other appropriately widely-accepted units. (b) At least one living and conscious biological human is continuously located beyond 100km altitude above Earth's mean sea level at all times until 1 January 2050, including aboard spacecraft, space stations, or on astronomical objects other than Earth. This includes humans with some degree of cybernetic augmentation capable of reproducing with un-augmented humans. Resolves NO if neither of these conditions are met.

Q_or_P.title: Will either humanity maintain a continuous off-Earth presence until 2050 or will there be a 4 year interval in which world output doubles before 2050?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for each part:

1. Humanity maintaining a continuous off-Earth presence until 2050: For a positive resolution, at least one living and conscious biological human must be physically located at some point beyond 100km altitude above Earth's mean sea level at all times continuously until 1 January 2050. This could include persons aboard spacecraft and space stations, as well as persons on any astronomical object other than Earth (e.g., Moon or Mars explorers/settlers). If the number of living and conscious biological humans off-Earth drops to zero at any time before 1 January 2050, this question resolves negatively. EMs, artificial intelligence systems, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and all other instances of either wholly non-biological or non-conscious humans will not count for the purposes of this question. Humans who are merely sleeping will be considered conscious for the purposes of this question. However, biological humans with some degree of cybernetic augmentation (brain implants, artificial limbs or organs, etc) will suffice, so long as they could still reproduce with un-augmented humans.

2. A 4 year interval in which world output doubles before 2050: This question will resolve positively if world output doubles in a period of 4 years or less before 2050. It resolves negatively otherwise, i.e. if the following related question resolves ambiguously: [Will there be a complete 4 year interval in which world output doubles, before the first 1 year interval in which world output doubles?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/736/will-…

This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2019 and January 1, 2050, both of these conditions are true:
There is a military conflict involving countries representing in totality at least 30% of world GDP in PPP or 50% of world population in any year in which the conflict is ongoing.
At least 10 million people (civillians or military personnel) have been killed in the conflict.

Q.title: Will synthetic biological weapons infect 100 people by 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a credible medical source announces at least 100 people are confirmed "infected" by one or more confirmed synthetic "biological weapon"s and that this has occured before 2030. The consequences of infection may or may not be immediately harmful. An agent can even be latent, or cause a delayed onset of disease, as long as the agent is still present and functional 24 hrs after infection (as opposed to being destroyed by the immune system). But if it causes some definite, confirmed harmful effect, and then self-destructs before 24 hrs have passed, that would still count. The infection can result from a terrorist attack, attack on enemy military personnel, an experiment, accident, with the infected persons' consent, or from any other cause

P_or_Q.title: Will either a "World War Three" occur before 2050 or will synthetic biological weapons infect 100 people by 2030?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: 
1. There is a military conflict involving countries representing in totality at least 30% of world GDP in PPP or 50% of world population in any year in which the conflict is ongoing, and at least 10 million people (civilians or military personnel) have been killed in the conflict, anytime between January 1, 2019 and January 1, 2050. 
2. A credible medical source announces at least 100 people are confirmed "infected" by one or more confirmed synthetic "biological weapon"s and that this has occurred before 2030. The consequences of infection may or may not be immediately harmful. An agent can even be latent, or cause a delayed onset of disease, as long as the agent is still present and functional 24 hrs after infection. 
Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will either synthetic biological weapons infect 100 people by 2030 or will there be a "World War Three" before 2050?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if either of the following conditions is met:
1. A credible medical source announces at least 100 people are confirmed "infected" by one or more confirmed synthetic "biological weapon"s before 2030. The consequences of infection may or may not be immediately harmful. An agent can be latent, or cause a delayed onset of disease, as long as the agent is still present and functional 24 hrs after infection. If it causes some definite, confirmed harmful effect, and then self-destructs before 24 hrs have passed, that would still count. The infection can result from a terrorist attack, attack on enemy military personnel, an experiment, accident, with the infected persons' consent, or from any other cause.
2. There is a military conflict involving countries representing in totality at least 30% of world GDP in PPP or 50% of world population in any year in which the conflict is ongoing, and at least 10 million people (civilians or military personnel) have been killed in the conflict, anytime between January 1, 2019 and January 1, 2050.
Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will any state test a nuclear weapon with yield above 30 MT by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2030, there are reports of such a test by reputable sources

Q.title: Ragnarök Question Series: if a nuclear catastrophe occurs, will it reduce the human population by 95% or more?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
In the first part of the Ragnarök Question Series, we asked the question If a global catastrophe happens before 2100, will it be principally due to the deployment of nuclear weapons?. Now it is asked,
Given that nuclear catastrophe occurs that results in the reduction of global population of at least 10% by 2100, will the global population decline by more than 95% relative to the pre-catastrophe population?
The question resolves ambiguous if a global nuclear catastrophe that claims at least 10% (in any period of 5 years or less) does not occur. It resolves positively if such a catastrophe does occur, and the global population is less than 5% of the pre-catastrophe population at any point within 25 years of the catastrophe. The question resolves negative if a global nuclear catastrophe occurs that claims at least 10% (in any period of 5 years or less) but the post-catastrophe population remains above 5%.

P_or_Q.title: Will either any state test a nuclear weapon with yield above 30 MT by 2030 or, given a nuclear catastrophe, will it reduce the human population by 95% or more?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for each part:
1. The question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2030, there are reports of a nuclear weapon test with a yield above 30 MT by any state, as reported by reputable sources.
2. Given that a nuclear catastrophe occurs that results in the reduction of the global population of at least 10% by 2100, this question will resolve positively if the global population declines by more than 95% relative to the pre-catastrophe population at any point within 25 years of the catastrophe. It resolves negatively if a global nuclear catastrophe occurs that claims at least 10% (in any period of 5 years or less) but the post-catastrophe population remains above 5%. The question resolves ambiguous if a global nuclear catastrophe that claims at least 10% does not occur.
The combined question resolves YES if either of the above conditions are met. It resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will either a nuclear catastrophe reduce the human population by 95% or more, or will any state test a nuclear weapon with yield above 30 MT by 2030?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for each part:
1. Given that a nuclear catastrophe occurs that results in the reduction of global population of at least 10% by 2100, will the global population decline by more than 95% relative to the pre-catastrophe population? The question resolves ambiguous if a global nuclear catastrophe that claims at least 10% (in any period of 5 years or less) does not occur. It resolves positively if such a catastrophe does occur, and the global population is less than 5% of the pre-catastrophe population at any point within 25 years of the catastrophe. The question resolves negative if a global nuclear catastrophe occurs that claims at least 10% (in any period of 5 years or less) but the post-catastrophe population remains above 5%.
2. Will any state test a nuclear weapon with yield above 30 MT by 2030? The question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2030, there are reports of such a test by reputable sources.

The overall question resolves YES if either of the above conditions are met. It resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will the US set a new annual GDP growth rate record high before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Real GDP Annual Growth Rate in the United States averaged 3.3% from 1930 until 2017, reaching an all time high of 8.7% in 1950 and a record low of -3.90% in the second quarter of 2009.
This question asks: In any year before Q1 2030, will the US record real GDP annual growth rate of greater than 8.7%, beating the record set in 1950?
For the purpose of this question, we shall refer to Real GDP in terms of percent change from preceding year, as provided by the Bureau of Economic Analysis, or other reputable sources of economic data.
Edit: (22 Feb 2019), the question now resolves positively if real GDP in terms of percent change from preceding year exceeds 8.7% instead of resolving positively if annualised quarterly real GDP growth exceeds 13.4%.

Q.title: Will photonic tensor cores be ubiquitous in machine learning by 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves as YES if photonic tensor cores are ubiquitous in machine learning by 2030, and NO otherwise.
Photonic tensor cores are said to be "ubiquitous" in machine learning by 2030 if all three of the top machine learning cloud computing services offer photonic tensor cores for training models. The top machine learning cloud computing services are taken to the top three services that are yielded by the DuckDuckGo search, "machine learning cloud computing service" (If DuckDuckGo is no longer available, the following take their place in order of priority: Google, Bing).
Show More

P_or_Q.title: Will either the US set a new annual GDP growth rate record high before 2030, or will photonic tensor cores be ubiquitous in machine learning by 2030?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) In any year before Q1 2030, the US records a real GDP annual growth rate of greater than 8.7%, beating the record set in 1950, as measured in terms of percent change from the preceding year by the Bureau of Economic Analysis or other reputable sources of economic data. (b) Photonic tensor cores are ubiquitous in machine learning by 2030, defined as all three of the top machine learning cloud computing services offering photonic tensor cores for training models, where the top services are determined by the DuckDuckGo search for "machine learning cloud computing service" (or Google, Bing if DuckDuckGo is unavailable). Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will either photonic tensor cores be ubiquitous in machine learning by 2030 or the US set a new annual GDP growth rate record high before 2030?
Q_or_P.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) Photonic tensor cores are ubiquitous in machine learning by 2030, defined as all three of the top machine learning cloud computing services offering photonic tensor cores for training models. The top services are determined by a DuckDuckGo search for "machine learning cloud computing service" (or Google, Bing if DuckDuckGo is unavailable). (b) The US records a real GDP annual growth rate greater than 8.7% in any year before Q1 2030, beating the record set in 1950. Real GDP is considered in terms of percent change from the preceding year, as provided by the Bureau of Economic Analysis or other reputable sources. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Longbets series: By 2030, will commercial passengers routinely fly in pilotless planes?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Craig J Mundie and Eric Schmidt summarize their reasons for taking the bet here.
If the Long Now Foundation declares Craig J Mundie the winner, this question resolves positively. If they declare Eric Schmidt the winner, this question resolves negatively.

Q.title: Will an oracle superintelligence be developed before a general superintelligence?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will immediately resolve positively if an AI limited to answering questions achieves reliably superhuman performance across virtually all questions of interest before an AI achieves generally superhuman performance across virtually all human activities of interest. If a generally superhuman AI is developed first, the question will immediately resolve negatively. By default, the question will resolve ambiguously on the resolve date, 2099-12-31.
Successful creation of either technology would presumably be extremely obvious and uncontroversial, with a great amount of media coverage and scientific attention. However, if there is significant disagreement over whether a given apparent achievement resolves the question, it will be determined by Metaculus moderators

P_or_Q.title: Will either commercial passengers routinely fly in pilotless planes by 2030 or an oracle superintelligence be developed before a general superintelligence?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) The Long Now Foundation declares Craig J Mundie the winner, indicating that commercial passengers routinely fly in pilotless planes by 2030. (b) An AI limited to answering questions achieves reliably superhuman performance across virtually all questions of interest before an AI achieves generally superhuman performance across virtually all human activities of interest. Resolves NO if Eric Schmidt is declared the winner by The Long Now Foundation, indicating that commercial passengers do not routinely fly in pilotless planes by 2030, or if a generally superhuman AI is developed first. The question will resolve ambiguously on the resolve date, 2099-12-31, if neither condition is clearly met. Successful creation of either technology would presumably be extremely obvious and uncontroversial, with a great amount of media coverage and scientific attention. However, if there is significant disagreement over whether a given apparent achievement resolves the question, it will be determined by Metaculus moderators.

Q_or_P.title: Will either an oracle superintelligence be developed before a general superintelligence, or will commercial passengers routinely fly in pilotless planes by 2030?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for each event:
1. This question will resolve positively if an AI limited to answering questions achieves reliably superhuman performance across virtually all questions of interest before an AI achieves generally superhuman performance across virtually all human activities of interest. If a generally superhuman AI is developed first, or if there is significant disagreement over whether a given apparent achievement resolves the question, it will be determined by Metaculus moderators. By default, this part will resolve ambiguously on 2099-12-31.
2. If the Long Now Foundation declares Craig J Mundie the winner, this question resolves positively. If they declare Eric Schmidt the winner, this question resolves negatively.

The question resolves YES if either event 1 or event 2 resolves positively. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will Metaculus predict that artificial intelligence continues to pose a global catastrophic risk by 2040?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Currently, artificial intelligence can outperform humans in a number of narrow domains, such as playing chess and searching data. As artificial intelligence researchers continue to make progress, though, these domains are highly likely to grow in number and breadth over time. Many experts now believe there is a significant chance that a machine superintelligence – a system that can outperform humans at all relevant intelligence tasks – will be developed within the next century, and possibly much sooner.
As predictions to a previous question suggest, artificial intelligence might pose a global catastrophic risk (defined there as a 10% decrease in the world population in any period of 5 years). When considering how AI might become a risk, experts think two scenarios most likely, according to the Future of Life Institute:
The AI is programmed to do something devastating: Autonomous weapons are artificial intelligence systems that are programmed to kill. In the hands of the wrong person, these weapons could easily cause mass casualties. Moreover, an AI arms race could inadvertently lead to an AI war that also results in mass casualties. To avoid being thwarted by the enemy, these weapons would be designed to be extremely difficult to simply “turn off,” so humans could plausibly lose control of such a situation. This risk is one that’s present even with narrow AI, but grows as levels of AI intelligence and autonomy increase.
The AI is programmed to do something beneficial, but it develops a destructive method for achieving its goal: This can happen whenever we fail to fully align the AI’s goals with ours, which is strikingly difficult. If you ask an obedient intelligent car to take you to the airport as fast as possible, it might get you there chased by helicopters and covered in vomit, doing not what you wanted but literally what you asked for. If a superintelligent system is tasked with a ambitious geoengineering project, it might wreak havoc with our ecosystem as a side effect, and view human attempts to stop it as a threat to be met. As these examples illustrate, the concern about advanced AI isn’t malevolence but competence. A super-intelligent AI will be extremely good at accomplishing its goals, and if those goals aren’t aligned with ours, we have a problem.
It is thought by some that reducing the second of these two risks will require progress in technical methods of developing scalable control methods that could ensure that a AI will be safe and will behave as its programmers intend even if its intellectual capabilities are increased to arbitrary levels. Until recently, this problem was almost entirely neglected; but in the last couple of years, technical research agendas have been developed, and there are now several research groups pursuing work in this area. Total investment in long-term AI safety, however, remains orders of magnitude less than investment in increasing AI capability. Additionally, reducing the first of the listed risks might require improvements in our ability to control, govern and coordinate on the usage of such systems, so to reduce potential security threats from malicious uses of AI technologies.
But how certain are we that artificial intelligence continue to be regarded to constitute a large chunk of global catastrophic risk, at least through 2040? A previous question asked: If a global catastrophe happens before 2100, will it be principally due to the deployment of some Artificial Intelligence system(s)?
Will the probability (of both the Metaculus and community predictions) artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe (given that a global catastrophe does occur) remain above 5% in each 6-month period before 2040?
This question resolves positively if both the Metaculus and community predictions) of artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe fail to fall below 5% for any 6-month period before 2040, as will be confirmed by one of the Metaculus admins.

Q.title: Will humanity maintain a continuous off-Earth presence until 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Since October 31 2000, the date Soyuz TM-31 lifted off from the Baikonur Cosmodrome carrying the members of Expedition 1, the first long-duration ISS crew, humanity has maintained a permanent off-Earth presence for more than 19 years.
This question asks: Will humanity maintain an off-Earth presence continuously until 1 January 2050?
For a positive resolution, at least one living and conscious biological human must be physically located at some point beyond 100km altitude above Earth's mean sea level at all times continuously until 1 January 2050. This could include persons aboard spacecraft and space stations, as well as persons on any astronomical object other than Earth (e.g. Moon or Mars explorers / settlers).
If the number of living and conscious biological humans off-Earth drops to zero at any time before 1 January 2050, this question resolves negatively. EMs, artificial intelligence systems, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and all other instances of either wholly non-biological or non-conscious humans will not count for the purposes of this question. Humans who are merely sleeping will be considered conscious for the purposes of this question.
However, biological humans with some degree of cybernetic augmentation (brain implants, artificial limbs or organs, etc) will suffice, so long as they could still reproduce with un-augmented humans.

P_or_Q.title: Will Metaculus predict that artificial intelligence continues to pose a global catastrophic risk by 2040 or will humanity maintain a continuous off-Earth presence until 2050?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) Metaculus and community predictions of artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe remain above 5% for any 6-month period before 2040, as confirmed by a Metaculus admin. This includes the consideration that artificial intelligence might pose a global catastrophic risk, defined as a 10% decrease in the world population in any period of 5 years, and involves scenarios where AI is programmed to do something devastating or beneficial but develops a destructive method for achieving its goal. (b) At least one living and conscious biological human is physically located beyond 100km altitude above Earth's mean sea level at all times continuously until 1 January 2050. This includes persons aboard spacecraft and space stations, as well as persons on any astronomical object other than Earth (e.g., Moon or Mars explorers/settlers). EMs, artificial intelligence systems, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and all other instances of either wholly non-biological or non-conscious humans will not count for the purposes of this question. Humans who are merely sleeping will be considered conscious for the purposes of this question. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will either humanity maintain a continuous off-Earth presence until 2050 or Metaculus predict that artificial intelligence continues to pose a global catastrophic risk by 2040?
Q_or_P.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) At least one living and conscious biological human is physically located beyond 100km altitude above Earth's mean sea level at all times continuously until 1 January 2050. This includes persons aboard spacecraft and space stations, as well as persons on any astronomical object other than Earth (e.g., Moon or Mars explorers/settlers). If the number of such humans drops to zero at any time before 1 January 2050, this part of the question resolves negatively. EMs, artificial intelligence systems, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and all other instances of either wholly non-biological or non-conscious humans will not count. Humans who are merely sleeping will be considered conscious. Biological humans with some degree of cybernetic augmentation will suffice, so long as they could still reproduce with un-augmented humans. (b) The probability (of both the Metaculus and community predictions) that artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe (given that a global catastrophe does occur) remains above 5% in each 6-month period before 2040, as confirmed by one of the Metaculus admins. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will the European Union meet its 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a credible news report cites an analysis independent of the European Union government confirming that Europe has met all three 2030 climate action goals, including emission reduction by at least 40% below 1990 levels, on or before January 1, 2030.
Fine Print
The EU has updated its goals under the Paris Agreement, but this question will use the original goals in place at the time the question was written, specifically the three below.
40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030, compared to 2019
At least 27% of total energy consumption from renewable energy
At least 27% increase in energy efficiency in comparison with projections

Q.title: Will the famed South American lithium triangle (Bolivia, Chile, and Argentina) overtake Australia in lithium production before 2031?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the amount of lithium mine production between Argentina, Chile, and Bolivia is greater than the mine production from Australia before the end of 2030. Data will be provided through Statista, which has current data on both the countries with the greatest lithium reserves as of 2019, as well as data on lithium production by country ranging from 2014-2019.
This question will resolve ambiguously if data is no longer available through Statista and no other credible source can be found, or if lithium demand by the transportation industry drops below 1 kilotonne. Demand in 2019 was at approximately 17 kt in comparison

P_or_Q.title: Will either the European Union meet its 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty or the South American lithium triangle overtake Australia in lithium production before 2031?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria:
This question will resolve as YES if either of the following occurs:
1. A credible news report cites an analysis independent of the European Union government confirming that Europe has met all three 2030 climate action goals, including emission reduction by at least 40% below 1990 levels, on or before January 1, 2030. The goals are: a 40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 compared to 1990 levels, at least 27% of total energy consumption from renewable energy, and at least 27% increase in energy efficiency in comparison with projections.
2. The combined lithium mine production from Argentina, Chile, and Bolivia is greater than the mine production from Australia before the end of 2030, based on data from Statista or another credible source if Statista data is unavailable. This question will resolve ambiguously if data is no longer available through Statista and no other credible source can be found, or if lithium demand by the transportation industry drops below 1 kilotonne.
Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will either the South American lithium triangle overtake Australia in lithium production before 2031 or the European Union meet its 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for the South American lithium triangle and Australia: This question will resolve positively if the amount of lithium mine production between Argentina, Chile, and Bolivia is greater than the mine production from Australia before the end of 2030. Data will be provided through Statista, which has current data on both the countries with the greatest lithium reserves as of 2019, as well as data on lithium production by country ranging from 2014-2019. This question will resolve ambiguously if data is no longer available through Statista and no other credible source can be found, or if lithium demand by the transportation industry drops below 1 kilotonne. Demand in 2019 was at approximately 17 kt in comparison.

Resolution Criteria for the European Union: This question will resolve as Yes if a credible news report cites an analysis independent of the European Union government confirming that Europe has met all three 2030 climate action goals, including emission reduction by at least 40% below 1990 levels, on or before January 1, 2030. The EU has updated its goals under the Paris Agreement, but this question will use the original goals in place at the time the question was written, specifically the three below: 40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030, compared to 2019; at least 27% of total energy consumption from renewable energy; at least 27% increase in energy efficiency in comparison with projections.

P.title: Does P = NP?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
If no award is given by the Clay Institute (between January 1, 2000 to January 1, 2100) for a proof or disproof of P = NP, this question will resolve ambiguously. The question will resolve ambiguously also if the problem is proven to not have a solution either way, e.g. if the problem will turn out to be unprovable or undecidable. If resolution is positive, the close date will be set retroactively to the date of complete initial publication (in journal or preprint form) of the proof, plus one year (or one day before the date of announcement of the prize, if that comes earlier.)
As some background, Gerhard J. Woeginger maintains a list of claimed proofs of the problem. As of 2018, the list contains 62 purported proofs of P = NP, 50 of P ≠ NP, 2 proofs the problem is unprovable, and one proof that it is undecidable. William I. Gasarch asked 100 various theorists the question whether P = NP. The result are as follows:
61 thought P≠NP.
9 thought P=NP.
4 thought that it is independent.
3 just stated that it is NOT independent of Primitive Recursive Arithmetic.
1 said it would depend on the model.
22 offered no opinion

Q.title: Will AES-256 be publicly broken by 2040?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Anything that is not a computationally feasible break of the algorithm itself will not resolve positive. For example, any kind of dictionary attack, including AI-generated dictionaries, does not resolve positive. Side-channel attacks do not resolve positive. Any other attacks on implementations of AES-256, but not the specification for the AES-256 algorithm itself, do not resolve positive. Non-cryptographic means of key recovery, such as interrogation, brain scan, theft or espionage do not resolve positive.
This question resolves positive if before 12:01 AM GMT on January 1 2040 a credible, practically demonstrated* means of determining a AES-256 secret key without any special knowledge except the given ciphertext is made known to the public. Correspondingly, attacks that require a plaintext or more than one ciphertext for a given key do not resolve positive.
*"Practically demonstrated" means that a successful attack against AES-256 was actually carried out

P_or_Q.title: Will either P = NP be proven or disproven, or will AES-256 be publicly broken by 2040?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for P = NP:
If no award is given by the Clay Institute (between January 1, 2000 to January 1, 2100) for a proof or disproof of P = NP, this question will resolve ambiguously. The question will resolve ambiguously also if the problem is proven to not have a solution either way, e.g. if the problem will turn out to be unprovable or undecidable. If resolution is positive, the close date will be set retroactively to the date of complete initial publication (in journal or preprint form) of the proof, plus one year (or one day before the date of announcement of the prize, if that comes earlier).

Resolution Criteria for AES-256:
This question resolves positive if before 12:01 AM GMT on January 1, 2040 a credible, practically demonstrated means of determining a AES-256 secret key without any special knowledge except the given ciphertext is made known to the public. Attacks that require a plaintext or more than one ciphertext for a given key do not resolve positive. Non-cryptographic means of key recovery, such as interrogation, brain scan, theft or espionage do not resolve positive.

The question resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (1) P = NP is proven or disproven according to the specified criteria, or (2) AES-256 is publicly broken by 2040 according to the specified criteria. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will either AES-256 be publicly broken by 2040 or will P = NP be resolved?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: 

(1) Before 12:01 AM GMT on January 1, 2040, a credible, practically demonstrated means of determining an AES-256 secret key without any special knowledge except the given ciphertext is made known to the public. This excludes dictionary attacks, side-channel attacks, attacks on implementations not on the AES-256 specification itself, and non-cryptographic means of key recovery such as interrogation, brain scan, theft, or espionage. Attacks requiring plaintext or more than one ciphertext for a given key also do not resolve positive.

(2) The problem of whether P = NP is resolved, either by proof or disproof, and recognized by the award of a prize by the Clay Institute between January 1, 2000, and January 1, 2100. If the problem is proven to be unprovable or undecidable, or if no award is given by the Clay Institute for a proof or disproof, the question will resolve ambiguously.

Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will Mars have a permanent population of 10,000 before the Moon does?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Mars is often disussed as a target for mass colonization and eventual terraforming, notably by SpaceX. The Moon does not seem to be viewed as a future 'alternative' to Earth in the same way that Mars is.
Stats to consider:
Distance
Mars: between 55 and 400 million km from Earth (0.37 to 2.7 AU). It comes nearest to Earth every 2.14 years, or ~26 months.
The Moon: ~0.38 million km from Earth (~0.0026 AU).
One-way communication lag
Mars: between 3 to 22 minutes
The Moon: ~1.3 seconds
Gravity
Mars: 0.38 g
The Moon: 0.17 g
Rotation period
Mars: 25 hours
The Moon: 1 month
Atmosphere
Mars: mostly CO2, at ~1% the pressure of Earth's.
The Moon: negligible if any.
Solar energy
Mars: ~44% of Earth's, but occasional dust storms can bring this down to almost nothing.
The Moon: same as Earth's, but with no clouds or other interference.
This question is resolved when either the Moon or Mars has 10,000 people living on the body who have been residents for 3+ years at the time of counting. I've chosen 3 years to exclude people who arrive on Mars during one Earth-Mars opposition and leave during the next.
Residents of Phobos and Deimos, or of satellites in orbit around either body, are not counted for this question.
'Residence' is defined and determined by the government or entity administering the colony, or a similar official source.
In case political structures are substantially different, an admin may judge this question based on a different definitions of 'residence' that still captures the idea that it requires a person to have lived there for at least a relatively uninterrupted three years. Ems don't count as humans.
Resolves ambiguous if neither body meets the criterion by 2100.

Q.title: Will SpaceX land anything on Mars before 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a SpaceX-branded mission, where the primary launch hardware and Mars entry, descent, and landing systems are built by SpaceX, successfully lands on the surface of Mars by January 1, 2030. A landing's "success" will be judged by the intent of the mission according to SpaceX.
A "SpaceX-branded" mission is defined to mean that the SpaceX-associated logos on the spacecraft involved (both the boosters and the Mars-bound craft) have a larger surface area than the logos of any other entity

P_or_Q.body:

The Moon does not seem to be viewed as a future 'alternative' to Earth in the same way that Mars is. Residents of Phobos and Deimos, or of satellites in orbit around either body, are not counted for this question. 'Residence' is defined and determined by the government or entity administering the colony, or a similar official source. In case political structures are substantially different, an admin may judge this question based on a different definitions of 'residence' that still captures the idea that it requires a person to have lived there for at least a relatively uninterrupted three years. Ems don't count as humans. Resolves ambiguous if neither body meets the criterion by 2100.

Resolution Criteria for SpaceX landing on Mars before 2030: This question will resolve as Yes if a SpaceX-branded mission, where the primary launch hardware and Mars entry, descent, and landing systems are built by SpaceX, successfully lands on the surface of Mars by January 1, 2030. A landing's "success" will be judged by the intent of the mission according to SpaceX. A "SpaceX-branded" mission is defined to mean that the SpaceX-associated logos on the spacecraft involved (both the boosters and the Mars-bound craft) have a larger surface area than the logos of any other entity.

This question resolves YES if either of the above conditions are met. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will either SpaceX land anything on Mars before 2030 or Mars have a permanent population of 10,000 before the Moon does?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for SpaceX landing on Mars:
This question will resolve as Yes if a SpaceX-branded mission, where the primary launch hardware and Mars entry, descent, and landing systems are built by SpaceX, successfully lands on the surface of Mars by January 1, 2030. A landing's "success" will be judged by the intent of the mission according to SpaceX.
A "SpaceX-branded" mission is defined to mean that the SpaceX-associated logos on the spacecraft involved (both the boosters and the Mars-bound craft) have a larger surface area than the logos of any other entity.

Resolution Criteria for Mars vs. Moon population:
This question will resolve when either the Moon or Mars has 10,000 people living on the body who have been residents for 3+ years at the time of counting. Residents of Phobos and Deimos, or of satellites in orbit around either body, are not counted for this question. 'Residence' is defined and determined by the government or entity administering the colony, or a similar official source. In case political structures are substantially different, an admin may judge this question based on a different definitions of 'residence' that still captures the idea that it requires a person to have lived there for at least a relatively uninterrupted three years. Ems don't count as humans. Resolves ambiguous if neither body meets the criterion by 2100.

This question resolves YES if either of the above conditions are met. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will Xi Jinping continue leading China in 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positive if either:
Xi is CCP General Secretary on 1 January, 2030.
Xi is paramount leader of China on 1 January, 2030.
Xi is de facto leader of China on 1 January, 2030.
This question will resolve negative if:
Any other person is leader on 1 January, 2030.
This question will resolve ambiguous if:
China ceases to exist as the political entity it is right now

Q.title: Will there be a China-India war by 2035?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
For the purposes of this question, a China-India war is defined as the China and India collectively suffering at least 1,000 battle-related deaths in conflicts with each other in a single calendar year, as reported by credible news, government, or multi-national sources. Deaths in battles fought between the China and an ally of India or between India and an ally of the China will not count towards positive resolution. If this does not occur by January 1, 2035, this question will resolve negatively.
We here define battle related deaths as defined by the Uppsala University Department of Peace and Conflict Studies.
Resolution will come from reputable news sources, from official federal or military announcements, or from multinational institutions like the UN or NATO

P_or_Q.title: Will either Xi Jinping continue leading China in 2030 or will there be a China-India war by 2035?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for Xi Jinping leading China in 2030:
This question will resolve positive if any of the following occur:
- Xi is CCP General Secretary on 1 January, 2030.
- Xi is paramount leader of China on 1 January, 2030.
- Xi is de facto leader of China on 1 January, 2030.
This question will resolve negative if any other person is leader on 1 January, 2030.
This question will resolve ambiguous if China ceases to exist as the political entity it is right now.

Resolution Criteria for a China-India war by 2035:
For the purposes of this question, a China-India war is defined as China and India collectively suffering at least 1,000 battle-related deaths in conflicts with each other in a single calendar year, as reported by credible news, government, or multi-national sources. Deaths in battles fought between China and an ally of India or between India and an ally of China will not count towards positive resolution. If this does not occur by January 1, 2035, this question will resolve negatively.

This question will resolve YES if either of the above conditions are met. It will resolve NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will either a China-India war occur by 2035 or Xi Jinping continue leading China in 2030?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for China-India war:
For the purposes of this question, a China-India war is defined as China and India collectively suffering at least 1,000 battle-related deaths in conflicts with each other in a single calendar year, as reported by credible news, government, or multi-national sources. Deaths in battles fought between China and an ally of India or between India and an ally of China will not count towards positive resolution. If this does not occur by January 1, 2035, this question will resolve negatively. Battle related deaths are as defined by the Uppsala University Department of Peace and Conflict Studies. Resolution will come from reputable news sources, from official federal or military announcements, or from multinational institutions like the UN or NATO.

Resolution Criteria for Xi Jinping's leadership:
This question will resolve positive if either: Xi is CCP General Secretary on 1 January, 2030; Xi is paramount leader of China on 1 January, 2030; or Xi is de facto leader of China on 1 January, 2030. It will resolve negative if any other person is leader on 1 January, 2030. The question will resolve ambiguous if China ceases to exist as the political entity it is right now.

This combined question resolves YES if either the China-India war as defined occurs by 2035 or Xi Jinping continues leading China in 2030. It resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will US Non-Overseas Contingency operations military deaths exceed 3,000 in any calendar year before 2032?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the number of military deaths across all branches of the US armed forces is greater than 3,000 in any calendar year between 2019 and 2031 (inclusive), according to the Congressional Research Service. Deaths should include all branches of the US armed forces and all active duty troops, including mobilized Reserve and Guard components. The estimate should include only "Non-Overseas Contingency Operations". Contingency Operations are defined by CRS according to
Section 101 of Title 10, United States Code, defines a contingency operation as any Secretary of Defense-designated military operation “in which members of the armed forces are or may become involved in military actions, operations, or hostilities against an enemy of the United States or against an opposing military force.
If data by CRS is not available or complete between 2019 and 2031, Metaculus may select another credible source of data, or resolve as Ambiguous at their discretion

If before this question resolves NATO is dissolved, or changed in structure or operation so substantially that Metaculus administrators believe it is no longer prudent to continue this question, this question shall resolve as Ambiguous
