P.title: Will humans go extinct before 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if there are no known humans alive on January 1, 2100. For these purposes we'll define humans as biological creatures who have as their ancestors – via a chain of live births from mothers – circa 2000 humans OR who could mate with circa 2000 humans to produce viable offspring. (So AIs, ems, genetically engineered beings of a different species brought up in artificial wombs, etc. would not count). Any living humans living anywhere in the observable universe (or multiverse) (who are known to the entities operating Metaculus) on that date will be sufficient to resolve the question negatively.
N.B. Even though it is obviously the case that if human extinction occurs Metaculus points won't be very valuable anymore and that it will be practically impossible to check for true human extinction (zero humans left), I would like to ask people not to let this fact influence their prediction and to predict in good faith

Q.title: Will no non-test nuclear weapons be detonated before 2035?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if no nuclear weapon is detonated before Jan 1, 2035, outside of controlled tests. Negative resolution could be triggered by:
Deliberate nuclear attack.
Accidental nuclear attack (launched by accident or on the basis of erroneous information.)
Accidental detonation of a weapon.
Nuclear terrorism.
For these purposes we do not consider a radiological weapon — where any fission/fusion energy is energetically sub-dominant to chemical or other explosives — to constitute a nuclear detonation.
The deliberate detonation of nuclear weapons primarily for non-offensive engineering, mining or other civilian purposes (on Earth or in Space) do not trigger negative resolution.
See our related question Will no non-test nuclear weapons be detonated by start of 2024? </small

P_or_Q.title: Will either humans go extinct before 2100 or no non-test nuclear weapons be detonated before 2035?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) There are no known humans alive on January 1, 2100, where humans are defined as biological creatures who have as their ancestors – via a chain of live births from mothers – circa 2000 humans OR who could mate with circa 2000 humans to produce viable offspring. Any living humans anywhere in the observable universe (or multiverse) known to the entities operating Metaculus on that date will be sufficient to resolve the question negatively. (b) No nuclear weapon is detonated before Jan 1, 2035, outside of controlled tests. Negative resolution could be triggered by a deliberate nuclear attack, accidental nuclear attack (launched by accident or on the basis of erroneous information), accidental detonation of a weapon, or nuclear terrorism. Radiological weapons where any fission/fusion energy is energetically sub-dominant to chemical or other explosives do not constitute a nuclear detonation. Deliberate detonation of nuclear weapons primarily for non-offensive engineering, mining or other civilian purposes (on Earth or in Space) do not trigger negative resolution. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will either no non-test nuclear weapons be detonated before 2035 or humans go extinct before 2100?
Q_or_P.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) No nuclear weapon is detonated before Jan 1, 2035, outside of controlled tests. This includes no deliberate nuclear attacks, no accidental nuclear attacks (launched by accident or on the basis of erroneous information), no accidental detonation of a weapon, and no nuclear terrorism. Radiological weapons and deliberate detonations for non-offensive purposes do not count as nuclear detonations. (b) There are no known humans alive on January 1, 2100, defined as biological creatures who have as their ancestors – via a chain of live births from mothers – circa 2000 humans or who could mate with circa 2000 humans to produce viable offspring. Any living humans anywhere in the observable universe (or multiverse) known to the entities operating Metaculus on that date will resolve the question negatively. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Conditional on New START being renewed or replaced by another similar treaty after February 2026, will there be a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US by 2035?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question conditions on the following (i.e., it resolves ambiguously if this condition isn't met): New START is renewed or replaced by another similar treaty after February 2026, according to credible reports such as the [Arms Control Association]. By replacement by another nuclear arms control agreement we mean a situation when there is an agreement after 2026 that both US and Russian officials describe as a successor to New START. No attempt will be made to determine whether the renewed or replacement treaty actually has very similar terms to New START.
This question resolves positively if that condition is met and there is a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US between this question opening and 2035, defined here as at least one offensive nuclear detonation by the US on or over Russian territory and/or at least one offensive nuclear detonation made by Russia on or over US territory.
A state (US or Russia) will be considered responsible for a nuclear detonation if either:
(a) The state openly admits such responsibility (in a statement made by the President, Prime Minister, Minister/Secretary of Defense, the US Ambassador to Russia (or vice versa), a top military executive or a similarly important official)
(b) Credible reports by multinational organizations conclude that the state was responsible
(c) There are credible reports claiming the state was responsible and the state does not deny it.
If the state changes its claims (e.g. first admitting responsibility for the attack and then denying it), priority will be given to independent reports.
For the purposes of this question, offensive nuclear detonations include deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised detonations (see the fine print for definitions), but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes and peaceful nuclear explosions.
See also:
Will the New START nuclear arms control agreement be renewed until at least 5 February 2027?
Conditional on New START not being renewed or replaced by another similar treaty after February 2026, will there be a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US by 2035?
Fine Print
Detonations must occur less than 20 kilometers above the surface of the Earth in order to count as being on or over US/Russia territory.
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. If information is unclear, then resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins.
In a deliberate detonation, the attacking nation decides to launch one or more nuclear weapons either in response to a genuine nuclear attack or without believing that it is under nuclear attack. “In an inadvertent detonation, the attacking nation mistakenly concludes that it is under nuclear attack and launches one or more nuclear weapons in what it believes is a counterattack” (Barrett et al., 2013). “In an accidental or unauthorized launch or detonation, system safeguards or procedures to maintain control over nuclear weapons fail in such a way that a nuclear weapon or missile launches or explodes without direction from leaders” (Barrett et al., 2013).

Q.title: If there is at least one nuclear detonation by 2030, in which countries will there be at least one fatality? (Russia)
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This group is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occuring at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, all sub-questions below will resolve as Ambiguous.
If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, the following sub-questions will resolve as Yes if there is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occuring in that country (or regions), at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030. If there is no such fatality, the sub-question will resolve as No. If the only nuclear detonations in this period occur outside of all of the following areas (for example, they occur in international waters, or a region(s) not listed below), all options below will resolve as No.
The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by eg. fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution.
For this question, an "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations of by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions (even if such detonations cause substantial damage).
Fine Print
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. Final determination of whether a detonation is a test/peaceful detonation is at the sole discretion of Metaculus Admins.

A detonation will be considered "within" a given country if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in that country's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

P_or_Q.title: Will there be a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US by 2035 conditional on New START being renewed or replaced, or will there be at least one fatality in Russia from a nuclear detonation by 2030?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolves YES if either of the following conditions is met: 

1. Conditional on New START being renewed or replaced by another similar treaty after February 2026, there is a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US by 2035. A nuclear exchange is defined as at least one offensive nuclear detonation by the US on or over Russian territory and/or at least one offensive nuclear detonation made by Russia on or over US territory. A state will be considered responsible for a nuclear detonation if (a) the state openly admits such responsibility, (b) credible reports by multinational organizations conclude that the state was responsible, or (c) there are credible reports claiming the state was responsible and the state does not deny it. Detonations must occur less than 20 kilometers above the surface of the Earth to count as being on or over US/Russia territory. This question resolves ambiguously if New START is not renewed or replaced by another similar treaty after February 2026.

2. There is at least one fatality in Russia from any nuclear detonation occurring between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2030, conditional on at least one offensive nuclear detonation occurring anywhere on Earth in this period. An offensive nuclear detonation includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions. The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation. This sub-question resolves as Ambiguous if no offensive nuclear detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period.

Resolves NO if neither of the above conditions is met.

Q_or_P.title: Will there be at least one fatality in Russia from any offensive nuclear detonation by 2030, or will there be a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US by 2035 conditional on New START being renewed or replaced after February 2026?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for Russia Fatality Question:
This question is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occurring at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, this part of the question will resolve as Ambiguous.
If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, this part of the question will resolve as Yes if there is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occurring in Russia, at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030. The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by eg. fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution.

Resolution Criteria for Nuclear Exchange Question:
This question conditions on the following (i.e., it resolves ambiguously if this condition isn't met): New START is renewed or replaced by another similar treaty after February 2026. This question resolves positively if that condition is met and there is a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US between this question opening and 2035, defined here as at least one offensive nuclear detonation by the US on or over Russian territory and/or at least one offensive nuclear detonation made by Russia on or over US territory.

The question resolves YES if either of the conditions for Russia fatality or nuclear exchange are met. It resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will the total interest in Effective Altruism on Google Trends in 2030 be at least 0.2 times the total interest in 2017?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Will the total interest in Effective Altruism on Google Trends in 2030 be at least 0.2 times the total interest in 2017?
Total interest shall be defined as the sum of the individual monthly interest values over a year. Note that the linked-to Google Trends chart is for the search term 'Effective Altruism'.
Edit (29/11/18): this resolves ambigous if Google Trends ceases to exist, or makes substantial enough changes to their methodology for admins to think an ambiguous resolution is required.

Q.title: Will the control problem be solved before the creation of "weak" Artificial General Intelligence?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question will resolve as Yes if expert consensus is that the control problem is solved before the public demonstration of "weak" artificial general intelligence.
For the purposes of this question, "weak" AGI will be defined as meeting the qualifications in this question, the terms of which are reproduced in the fine print below.
Fine Print
A "weak" Artificial General Intelligence should be capable fo the following:
Able to reliably pass a Turing test of the type that would win the Loebner Silver Prize.
Able to score 90% or more on a robust version of the Winograd Schema Challenge, e.g. the "Winogrande" challenge or comparable data set for which human performance is at 90+%
Be able to score 75th percentile (as compared to the corresponding year's human students; this was a score of 600 in 2016) on all the full mathematics section of a circa-2015-2020 standard SAT exam, using just images of the exam pages and having less than ten SAT exams as part of the training data. (Training on other corpuses of math problems is fair game as long as they are arguably distinct from SAT exams.)
Be able to learn the classic Atari game "Montezuma's revenge" (based on just visual inputs and standard controls) and explore all 24 rooms based on the equivalent of less than 100 hours of real-time play (see closely-related question.)
By "unified" we mean that the system is integrated enough that it can, for example, explain its reasoning on an SAT problem or Winograd schema question, or verbally report its progress and identify objects during videogame play. (This is not really meant to be an additional capability of "introspection" so much as a provision that the system not simply be cobbled together as a set of sub-systems specialized to tasks like the above, but rather a single system applicable to many problems.)

P_or_Q.title: Will either the total interest in Effective Altruism on Google Trends in 2030 be at least 0.2 times the total interest in 2017, or the control problem be solved before the creation of "weak" Artificial General Intelligence?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) The total interest in Effective Altruism on Google Trends in 2030 is at least 0.2 times the total interest in 2017. Total interest is defined as the sum of the individual monthly interest values over a year. Note: This resolves ambiguous if Google Trends ceases to exist, or makes substantial enough changes to their methodology for admins to think an ambiguous resolution is required. (b) Expert consensus is that the control problem is solved before the public demonstration of "weak" artificial general intelligence, where "weak" AGI is defined as capable of reliably passing a Turing test of the type that would win the Loebner Silver Prize, scoring 90% or more on a robust version of the Winograd Schema Challenge, scoring 75th percentile on the full mathematics section of a circa-2015-2020 standard SAT exam, and learning the classic Atari game "Montezuma's revenge" and exploring all 24 rooms based on the equivalent of less than 100 hours of real-time play. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will either the control problem be solved before the creation of "weak" Artificial General Intelligence or the total interest in Effective Altruism on Google Trends in 2030 be at least 0.2 times the total interest in 2017?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question will resolve as YES if either of the following occurs:
1. Expert consensus is that the control problem is solved before the public demonstration of "weak" artificial general intelligence. For the purposes of this question, "weak" AGI is defined as meeting the following qualifications:
   - Able to reliably pass a Turing test of the type that would win the Loebner Silver Prize.
   - Able to score 90% or more on a robust version of the Winograd Schema Challenge, e.g. the "Winogrande" challenge or comparable data set for which human performance is at 90+%
   - Be able to score 75th percentile (as compared to the corresponding year's human students; this was a score of 600 in 2016) on all the full mathematics section of a circa-2015-2020 standard SAT exam, using just images of the exam pages and having less than ten SAT exams as part of the training data. (Training on other corpuses of math problems is fair game as long as they are arguably distinct from SAT exams.)
   - Be able to learn the classic Atari game "Montezuma's revenge" (based on just visual inputs and standard controls) and explore all 24 rooms based on the equivalent of less than 100 hours of real-time play.
   - The system is integrated enough that it can, for example, explain its reasoning on an SAT problem or Winograd schema question, or verbally report its progress and identify objects during videogame play.
2. The total interest in Effective Altruism on Google Trends in 2030 is at least 0.2 times the total interest in 2017. Total interest shall be defined as the sum of the individual monthly interest values over a year. Note that the linked-to Google Trends chart is for the search term 'Effective Altruism'.

This question resolves ambiguous if Google Trends ceases to exist, or makes substantial enough changes to their methodology for admins to think an ambiguous resolution is required.
Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will the New START nuclear arms control agreement be renewed until at least February 5, 2027?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if either of the following conditions occur:
There are credible reports such as by the Arms Control Association of New START being extended to at least February 5, 2027.
There are credible reports of New START being replaced by another nuclear arms control agreement that will last until at least February 5, 2027 and that US officials, Russian officials, and other credible sources describe as a successor to New START.
Fine Print
It is not necessary that the renewed or replacement treaty has very similar terms. But note that the second condition would not be met if one or two of the three relevant groups (US officials, Russian officials, or other credible sources) do not describe the treaty as a successor to New START.

Q.title: Will a nuclear weapon be detonated as an act of war by 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if there is any nuclear detonation as an act of war between January 1, 2020 and January 1, 2050. Resolution will be by credible media reports. The detonation must be deliberate; accidental, inadvertent, or testing/peaceful detonations will not qualify (see fine print). Attacks using strategic and tactical nuclear weapons are both sufficient to qualify.
[2021-11-23]: Edited to clarify the definition of "deliberate" detonations.
Fine Print
Barrett et al. 2013 defined terms to distinguish between causes of nuclear detonations:
In an accidental or unauthorized launch or detonation, system safeguards or procedures to maintain control over nuclear weapons fail in such a way that a nuclear weapon or missile launches or explodes without direction from leaders.
In an inadvertent detonation, the attacking nation mistakenly concludes that it is under nuclear attack and launches one or more nuclear weapons in what it believes is a counterattack.
In a deliberate detonation, the attacking nation decides to launch one or more nuclear weapons either in response to a genuine nuclear attack or without believing that it is under nuclear attack.

P_or_Q.title: Will either the New START nuclear arms control agreement be renewed until at least February 5, 2027, or a nuclear weapon be detonated as an act of war by 2050?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolves YES if either of the following conditions occur:
1. There are credible reports such as by the Arms Control Association of New START being extended to at least February 5, 2027, or there are credible reports of New START being replaced by another nuclear arms control agreement that will last until at least February 5, 2027 and that US officials, Russian officials, and other credible sources describe as a successor to New START. Note that the second condition would not be met if one or two of the three relevant groups (US officials, Russian officials, or other credible sources) do not describe the treaty as a successor to New START.
2. There is any nuclear detonation as an act of war between January 1, 2020 and January 1, 2050, as reported by credible media. The detonation must be deliberate; accidental, inadvertent, or testing/peaceful detonations will not qualify. Attacks using strategic and tactical nuclear weapons are both sufficient to qualify.
Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will either a nuclear weapon be detonated as an act of war by 2050 or the New START nuclear arms control agreement be renewed until at least February 5, 2027?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if any of the following conditions occur:
1. There is any nuclear detonation as an act of war between January 1, 2020 and January 1, 2050. The detonation must be deliberate; accidental, inadvertent, or testing/peaceful detonations will not qualify. Attacks using strategic and tactical nuclear weapons are both sufficient to qualify. Resolution will be by credible media reports.
2. There are credible reports such as by the Arms Control Association of New START being extended to at least February 5, 2027, or there are credible reports of New START being replaced by another nuclear arms control agreement that will last until at least February 5, 2027 and that US officials, Russian officials, and other credible sources describe as a successor to New START.
Fine Print
For the nuclear detonation: Barrett et al. 2013 defined terms to distinguish between causes of nuclear detonations: In an accidental or unauthorized launch or detonation, system safeguards or procedures to maintain control over nuclear weapons fail in such a way that a nuclear weapon or missile launches or explodes without direction from leaders. In an inadvertent detonation, the attacking nation mistakenly concludes that it is under nuclear attack and launches one or more nuclear weapons in what it believes is a counterattack. In a deliberate detonation, the attacking nation decides to launch one or more nuclear weapons either in response to a genuine nuclear attack or without believing that it is under nuclear attack.
For the New START agreement: It is not necessary that the renewed or replacement treaty has very similar terms. But note that the second condition would not be met if one or two of the three relevant groups (US officials, Russian officials, or other credible sources) do not describe the treaty as a successor to New START.

P.title: By 2100, will the human population decrease by at least 10% during any period of 5 years?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the human population (on Earth, and possibly elsewhere) decreases by at least 10% in any period of 5 years or less. Years are here defined as consecutive calendar years.
This question is part of the Ragnarök Question Series. Check out the other questions in the series:
If a global biological catastrophe occurs, will it reduce the human population by 95% or more?
If an artificial intelligence catastrophe occurs, will it reduce the human population by 95% or more?
If a nuclear catastrophe occurs, will it reduce the human population by 95% or more?
If a global climate disaster occurs by 2100, will the human population decline by 95% or more?
If a global nanotechnology catastrophe occurs by 2100, will the human population decline by 95% or more?
Also, please check out our questions on whether a global catastrophe will occur by 2100, and if so, which?:
By 2100 will the human population decrease by at least 10% during any period of 5 years?
Will such a catastrophe be due to either human-made climate change or geoengineering?
Will such a catastrophe be due to a nanotechnology failure-mode?
Will such a catastrophe be due to nuclear war?
Will such a catastrophe be due to an artificial intelligence failure-mode?
Will such a catastrophe be due to biotechnology or bioengineered organisms?
All results are analysed here, and will be updated periodically.
</small

Q.title: Will a US Census in 2070 or earlier show a decline in population?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a Census conducted before 2071 shows a drop in US population over the previous Census, according to official statistics from the United States Census Bureau. If the Census Bureau changes its name or merges into another entity, those statistics will be used instead

P_or_Q.title: Will either the human population decrease by at least 10% during any period of 5 years by 2100 or a US Census in 2070 or earlier show a decline in population?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if either of the following occurs: 
1. The human population (on Earth, and possibly elsewhere) decreases by at least 10% in any period of 5 years or less by 2100. Years are defined as consecutive calendar years. This question is part of the Ragnarök Question Series. 
2. A Census conducted before 2071 shows a drop in US population over the previous Census, according to official statistics from the United States Census Bureau. If the Census Bureau changes its name or merges into another entity, those statistics will be used instead.
Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will either a US Census before 2071 show a decline in population or the human population decrease by at least 10% during any 5-year period by 2100?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if either of the following occurs:
1. A Census conducted before 2071 shows a drop in US population over the previous Census, according to official statistics from the United States Census Bureau. If the Census Bureau changes its name or merges into another entity, those statistics will be used instead.
2. The human population (on Earth, and possibly elsewhere) decreases by at least 10% in any period of 5 years or less by 2100. Years are defined as consecutive calendar years.
This question is part of the Ragnarök Question Series, which includes various scenarios for significant population declines due to global catastrophes. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will humanity maintain a continuous off-Earth presence until 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Since October 31 2000, the date Soyuz TM-31 lifted off from the Baikonur Cosmodrome carrying the members of Expedition 1, the first long-duration ISS crew, humanity has maintained a permanent off-Earth presence for more than 19 years.
This question asks: Will humanity maintain an off-Earth presence continuously until 1 January 2050?
For a positive resolution, at least one living and conscious biological human must be physically located at some point beyond 100km altitude above Earth's mean sea level at all times continuously until 1 January 2050. This could include persons aboard spacecraft and space stations, as well as persons on any astronomical object other than Earth (e.g. Moon or Mars explorers / settlers).
If the number of living and conscious biological humans off-Earth drops to zero at any time before 1 January 2050, this question resolves negatively. EMs, artificial intelligence systems, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and all other instances of either wholly non-biological or non-conscious humans will not count for the purposes of this question. Humans who are merely sleeping will be considered conscious for the purposes of this question.
However, biological humans with some degree of cybernetic augmentation (brain implants, artificial limbs or organs, etc) will suffice, so long as they could still reproduce with un-augmented humans.

Q.title: Will a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
For these purposes we define "practical" as an operational high-temperature nuclear fusion reactor that can (a) produce a demonstrated positive energy balance exceeding 100 megawatts for more than one week, and (b) have a sustainable plan for long-term operations (e.g. no critical hard-to-replace components that would be radiation-damaged to inoperability in a matter of days or weeks, etc.) These are chosen to roughly match this question.
This question will resolve as Yes if the first such reactor is built in China, and will resolve as No if the first such reactor is built anywhere else.
If no such reactor is built before January 1, 2050, this question will resolve as Ambiguous

P_or_Q.title: Will either humanity maintain a continuous off-Earth presence until 2050 or a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) At least one living and conscious biological human is physically located beyond 100km altitude above Earth's mean sea level at all times continuously until 1 January 2050. This includes persons aboard spacecraft and space stations, as well as persons on any astronomical object other than Earth (e.g., Moon or Mars). If the number of such humans drops to zero at any time before 1 January 2050, this part resolves negatively. EMs, artificial intelligence systems, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and all other instances of either wholly non-biological or non-conscious humans will not count. Humans who are merely sleeping will be considered conscious. Biological humans with cybernetic augmentations that allow them to reproduce with un-augmented humans are included. (b) A practical nuclear fusion reactor is first developed in China, defined as an operational high-temperature nuclear fusion reactor that produces a positive energy balance exceeding 100 megawatts for more than one week and has a sustainable plan for long-term operations. This reactor must be built in China for a positive resolution. If the first such reactor is built elsewhere or not built before January 1, 2050, this part resolves as NO or Ambiguous respectively.

Q_or_P.title: Will either a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China or will humanity maintain a continuous off-Earth presence until 2050?
Q_or_P.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) A practical nuclear fusion reactor is first developed in China, defined as an operational high-temperature nuclear fusion reactor that can produce a demonstrated positive energy balance exceeding 100 megawatts for more than one week and have a sustainable plan for long-term operations (e.g., no critical hard-to-replace components that would be radiation-damaged to inoperability in a matter of days or weeks). This question will resolve as YES if the first such reactor is built in China, and as NO if the first such reactor is built anywhere else. If no such reactor is built before January 1, 2050, this question will resolve as Ambiguous. (b) Humanity maintains a continuous off-Earth presence until 1 January 2050, defined as at least one living and conscious biological human being physically located beyond 100km altitude above Earth's mean sea level at all times continuously until the specified date. This includes persons aboard spacecraft and space stations, as well as persons on any astronomical object other than Earth (e.g., Moon or Mars explorers/settlers). If the number of living and conscious biological humans off-Earth drops to zero at any time before 1 January 2050, this question resolves negatively. EMs, artificial intelligence systems, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and all other instances of either wholly non-biological or non-conscious humans will not count for the purposes of this question. Humans who are merely sleeping will be considered conscious for the purposes of this question. However, biological humans with some degree of cybernetic augmentation (brain implants, artificial limbs or organs, etc) will suffice, so long as they could still reproduce with un-augmented humans.

P.title: If China invades Taiwan before 2035, will Japan respond with military forces?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
If China does not launch a full-scale invasion of Taiwan before January 1, 2035, then this question will resolve as Ambiguous. If China does invade Taiwan, this question will resolve as Yes if Japan responds with military forces within 365 days from of the beginning of the Chinese invasion.
In line with our main question, China will be considered to have launched a full-scale invasion of Taiwan if either of these occur:
The Associated Press and the New York Times both report that the People's Republic of China has launched a full-scale invasion of Taiwan.
At least 1,000 military personnel from the People's Liberation Army have been deployed to Taiwan for the purpose of putting the sovereignty of the main island under PRC rule.
Japan will be considered to have responded with military forces if there is an offensive physical attack on Chinese infrastructure, ships, military personnel, or civilians, in direct retaliation to the full-scale invasion, and this attack is ordered by the Japanese government or Japanese military leadership. Cyberattacks will not be considered offensive physical attacks, but covert operations to e.g. assassinate Chinese nationals, will count

Q.title: Will no non-test nuclear weapons be detonated before 2035?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if no nuclear weapon is detonated before Jan 1, 2035, outside of controlled tests. Negative resolution could be triggered by:
Deliberate nuclear attack.
Accidental nuclear attack (launched by accident or on the basis of erroneous information.)
Accidental detonation of a weapon.
Nuclear terrorism.
For these purposes we do not consider a radiological weapon — where any fission/fusion energy is energetically sub-dominant to chemical or other explosives — to constitute a nuclear detonation.
The deliberate detonation of nuclear weapons primarily for non-offensive engineering, mining or other civilian purposes (on Earth or in Space) do not trigger negative resolution.
See our related question Will no non-test nuclear weapons be detonated by start of 2024? </small

P_or_Q.title: Will either China invade Taiwan before 2035 and Japan respond with military forces, or will no non-test nuclear weapons be detonated before 2035?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for China and Japan: If China does not launch a full-scale invasion of Taiwan before January 1, 2035, then this question will resolve as Ambiguous. If China does invade Taiwan, this question will resolve as Yes if Japan responds with military forces within 365 days from the beginning of the Chinese invasion. China will be considered to have launched a full-scale invasion of Taiwan if either of these occur: The Associated Press and the New York Times both report that the People's Republic of China has launched a full-scale invasion of Taiwan, or at least 1,000 military personnel from the People's Liberation Army have been deployed to Taiwan for the purpose of putting the sovereignty of the main island under PRC rule. Japan will be considered to have responded with military forces if there is an offensive physical attack on Chinese infrastructure, ships, military personnel, or civilians, in direct retaliation to the full-scale invasion, and this attack is ordered by the Japanese government or Japanese military leadership. Cyberattacks will not be considered offensive physical attacks, but covert operations to e.g. assassinate Chinese nationals, will count.

Resolution Criteria for Nuclear Weapons: This question will resolve positively if no nuclear weapon is detonated before Jan 1, 2035, outside of controlled tests. Negative resolution could be triggered by: Deliberate nuclear attack, accidental nuclear attack (launched by accident or on the basis of erroneous information), accidental detonation of a weapon, or nuclear terrorism. For these purposes, a radiological weapon — where any fission/fusion energy is energetically sub-dominant to chemical or other explosives — does not constitute a nuclear detonation. The deliberate detonation of nuclear weapons primarily for non-offensive engineering, mining or other civilian purposes (on Earth or in Space) do not trigger negative resolution.

Q_or_P.title: Will either no non-test nuclear weapons be detonated before 2035, or will Japan respond with military forces if China invades Taiwan before 2035?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for each part:

1. **No non-test nuclear weapons detonated before 2035:** This question will resolve positively if no nuclear weapon is detonated before Jan 1, 2035, outside of controlled tests. Negative resolution could be triggered by any of the following: Deliberate nuclear attack, accidental nuclear attack (launched by accident or on the basis of erroneous information), accidental detonation of a weapon, or nuclear terrorism. Radiological weapons and deliberate detonations for non-offensive purposes do not count as nuclear detonations.

2. **Japan's response if China invades Taiwan before 2035:** This question will resolve as Ambiguous if China does not launch a full-scale invasion of Taiwan before January 1, 2035. If China does invade Taiwan, it will resolve as Yes if Japan responds with military forces within 365 days from the beginning of the invasion. A full-scale invasion is confirmed if reported by the Associated Press and the New York Times, or if at least 1,000 military personnel from the People's Liberation Army are deployed to Taiwan. Japan's response must be an offensive physical attack ordered by the Japanese government or military leadership; cyberattacks do not count, but covert operations like assassination do.

The question resolves YES if either of the above conditions are met. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will any state test a nuclear weapon with yield above 30 MT by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2030, there are reports of such a test by reputable sources

Q.title: If there's a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030, will this cause >400 million fatalities?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question conditions on there being a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030, using the same specification as in a previous question (except that here the year 2030 is used instead of 2024[1]). That is, the question resolves ambiguously if that condition isn't met. As noted in that previous question, this could be caused either by nuclear conflict or by something else.
The question resolves positively if:
The above condition is met
At least three credible sources state or estimate that, within 5 years of the end of the year in which the first 10% shortfall by 2030 occurs, more than 400 million fatalities were caused by that shortfall.
For example, if the shortfall occurs in 2027, this question is about whether that causes >400m fatalities by the end of 2032.
If a source gives a range as its estimate, the midpoint of that range will be used as its estimate.
See also:
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations cause >1m fatalities within 1 month of the final detonation?
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations cause >100m fatalities within 1 month of the final detonation?
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations cause >1b fatalities within 10 years of the final detonation?
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >1000 detonations cause >4b fatalities within 10 years of the final detonation?
Fine Print
For simplicity, no attempt will be made to second-guess credible sources on what fatalities should be considered to be "caused" by the 10% shortfall. For example, if the 10% shortfall is followed by armed conflict, no attempt will be made to second-guess what credible sources say about whether the fatalities caused by that armed conflict should be considered to be ultimately caused by the 10% shortfall.
[1] The reason for using 2030 rather than 2024 for this question is that the fatalities and discussion of them may occur on a several-year delay from the actual shortfall. It therefore seemed unwise to force this question to resolve by 2024, and hence best to make this part of the long-term rather than calibration tournament.

P_or_Q.title: Will either any state test a nuclear weapon with yield above 30 MT by 2030, or will a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030 cause more than 400 million fatalities?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria:
1. The question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2030, there are reports of a nuclear test with a yield above 30 MT by any state from reputable sources.
2. This question conditions on there being a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030. It resolves positively if this condition is met and at least three credible sources state or estimate that, within 5 years of the end of the year in which the first 10% shortfall by 2030 occurs, more than 400 million fatalities were caused by that shortfall. For example, if the shortfall occurs in 2027, this question is about whether that causes >400m fatalities by the end of 2032. If a source gives a range as its estimate, the midpoint of that range will be used as its estimate.
The question resolves negatively if neither of these conditions are met.

Q_or_P.title: Will either a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030 cause >400 million fatalities or any state test a nuclear weapon with yield above 30 MT by 2030?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for each part:

1. For the agricultural shortfall: This question conditions on there being a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030, using the same specification as in a previous question. The question resolves positively if the above condition is met and at least three credible sources state or estimate that, within 5 years of the end of the year in which the first 10% shortfall by 2030 occurs, more than 400 million fatalities were caused by that shortfall. For example, if the shortfall occurs in 2027, this question is about whether that causes >400m fatalities by the end of 2032. If a source gives a range as its estimate, the midpoint of that range will be used as its estimate.

2. For the nuclear weapon test: The question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2030, there are reports of such a test by reputable sources.

The question resolves YES if either of the above conditions are met. It resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: If there is at least one nuclear detonation by 2030, in which countries will there be at least one fatality? (Russia)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This group is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occuring at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, all sub-questions below will resolve as Ambiguous.
If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, the following sub-questions will resolve as Yes if there is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occuring in that country (or regions), at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030. If there is no such fatality, the sub-question will resolve as No. If the only nuclear detonations in this period occur outside of all of the following areas (for example, they occur in international waters, or a region(s) not listed below), all options below will resolve as No.
The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by eg. fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution.
For this question, an "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations of by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions (even if such detonations cause substantial damage).
Fine Print
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. Final determination of whether a detonation is a test/peaceful detonation is at the sole discretion of Metaculus Admins.

A detonation will be considered "within" a given country if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in that country's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

Q.title: Will there be a major nuclear accident before 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if an event or series of events that begins between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030 is classified as a level seven Major Accident on the INES scale (with that classification being issued before January 1, 2031), by any of the following: a national nuclear regulatory authority (for example, any of the agencies featured on this list or this list), the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, the International Atomic Energy Agency, the Head of State or Head of Government of the country in which the incident takes place, or any Permanent Member of the United Nations Security Council

P_or_Q.title: Will there be either a fatality in Russia from an offensive nuclear detonation by 2030 or a major nuclear accident before 2030?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for fatalities from nuclear detonation in Russia:
This question is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occurring at any time between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, this part of the question will resolve as Ambiguous.
If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, this part will resolve as Yes if there is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occurring in Russia, at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030. The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by e.g., fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution. An "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions.

Resolution Criteria for major nuclear accident:
This question will resolve as Yes if an event or series of events that begins between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030 is classified as a level seven Major Accident on the INES scale (with that classification being issued before January 1, 2031), by any of the following: a national nuclear regulatory authority, the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, the International Atomic Energy Agency, the Head of State or Head of Government of the country in which the incident takes place, or any Permanent Member of the United Nations Security Council.

The question will resolve as Yes if either of the above conditions are met. It will resolve as No otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will there be a major nuclear accident before 2030 or will there be at least one fatality in Russia from a nuclear detonation by 2030?
Q_or_P.body:
This question will resolve as YES if either of the following occurs: 

1. An event or series of events that begins between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2030, is classified as a level seven Major Accident on the INES scale (with that classification being issued before January 1, 2031), by any of the following: a national nuclear regulatory authority, the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, the International Atomic Energy Agency, the Head of State or Head of Government of the country in which the incident takes place, or any Permanent Member of the United Nations Security Council.

2. There is at least one offensive nuclear detonation between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2030, and there is at least one fatality in Russia from any nuclear detonation occurring in that country (or regions) at any point between these dates. The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution. An "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions.

The question will resolve as NO if neither of these conditions are met.

P.title: Will there be a US-China war before 2035?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
For the purposes of this question, a US-China war is defined as the US and China collectively suffering at least 1,000 battle-related deaths in conflicts with each other in a single calendar year, as reported by credible news, government, or multi-national sources. Deaths in battles fought between the US and an ally of China or between China and an ally of the US will not count towards positive resolution. If this does not occur before January 1, 2035, this question will resolve negatively.
We here define battle related deaths as defined by the Uppsala University Department of Peace and Conflict Studies.
Resolution will come from reputable news sources, from official federal or military announcements, or from multinational institutions like the UN or NATO

Q.title: Will the next US presidential election also be considered fraudulent by the losing party?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
For the purpose of this question, the "losing party" is defined as the party whose presidential candidate is projected to come in second place in the electoral college vote count by both the AP and Fox News (see fine print). This question resolves positively if ANY of the following come true following the 2024 presidential election,
The losing candidate states that they consider the election result "fraudulent" or "rigged", or some very close synonym of those words, as determined by consensus in the comment section of this question. The losing candidate must make this claim before the scheduled inauguration. If there is a dispute as to whether the candidate did indeed say a close synonym of "fraudulent" or "rigged", and therefore a dispute over whether the word choice counts for positive resolution, then the following method of resolution will be used: if thesaurus.com lists "fraud", "fraudulent", or "rigged" as a synonym of the word, and at least one moderator agrees that it is a close synonym, then it counts for positive resolution.
The losing candidate refuses to concede two weeks following both the AP and Fox News projecting their opponent to win the election AND neither the AP or Fox News having retracted their projection in that time. For the purpose of this question, a concession is a clear statement from the candidate projected to lose that they have acknowledged their defeat, and that they accept the results of the election. The concession must not be retracted within 48 hours.
Fewer than 20% of congressional members of the losing party believe that their candidate lost the election as determined by credible media two weeks following both the AP and Fox News projecting the opposite-party candidate to win the election AND neither the AP or Fox News having retracted their projection in that time. By comparison, on December 7th 2020, just 27 congressional Republicans acknowledge Biden’s win according to the Washington Post.
A survey from the Morning Consult reveals that fewer than 30% of survey participants who are members of the losing party state that the election was "probably" or "definitely" free and fair in the most recent such survey following projections from both the AP and Fox News. The relevant survey for 2020 can be found here.
Otherwise, the question resolves negatively.
Fine Print
For the purpose of this question, a network is said to have "projected" a winner if they make some authoritative statement saying that the candidate has won the election, or will win the election once the votes are counted. Crucially, the network does not actually have to use the language of "projected" but as long as their reporting follows this definition, it counts as a projection.

P_or_Q.title: Will either a US-China war occur before 2035 or the next US presidential election be considered fraudulent by the losing party?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occur: (a) The US and China collectively suffer at least 1,000 battle-related deaths in conflicts with each other in a single calendar year before January 1, 2035, as reported by credible news, government, or multi-national sources. Deaths in battles fought between the US and an ally of China or between China and an ally of the US do not count towards positive resolution. (b) Any of the following conditions are met following the 2024 presidential election: the losing candidate states that they consider the election result "fraudulent" or "rigged", or a very close synonym of those words, before the scheduled inauguration; the losing candidate refuses to concede two weeks following both the AP and Fox News projecting their opponent to win the election and neither the AP or Fox News having retracted their projection in that time; fewer than 20% of congressional members of the losing party believe that their candidate lost the election two weeks following both the AP and Fox News projecting the opposite-party candidate to win the election and neither the AP or Fox News having retracted their projection in that time; a survey from the Morning Consult reveals that fewer than 30% of survey participants who are members of the losing party state that the election was "probably" or "definitely" free and fair in the most recent such survey following projections from both the AP and Fox News. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will either the next US presidential election be considered fraudulent by the losing party or will there be a US-China war before 2035?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for the US presidential election:
For the purpose of this question, the "losing party" is defined as the party whose presidential candidate is projected to come in second place in the electoral college vote count by both the AP and Fox News. This question resolves positively if ANY of the following come true following the 2024 presidential election:
1. The losing candidate states that they consider the election result "fraudulent" or "rigged", or some very close synonym of those words, as determined by consensus in the comment section of this question. The losing candidate must make this claim before the scheduled inauguration. If there is a dispute as to whether the candidate did indeed say a close synonym of "fraudulent" or "rigged", and therefore a dispute over whether the word choice counts for positive resolution, then the following method of resolution will be used: if thesaurus.com lists "fraud", "fraudulent", or "rigged" as a synonym of the word, and at least one moderator agrees that it is a close synonym, then it counts for positive resolution.
2. The losing candidate refuses to concede two weeks following both the AP and Fox News projecting their opponent to win the election AND neither the AP or Fox News having retracted their projection in that time. For the purpose of this question, a concession is a clear statement from the candidate projected to lose that they have acknowledged their defeat, and that they accept the results of the election. The concession must not be retracted within 48 hours.
3. Fewer than 20% of congressional members of the losing party believe that their candidate lost the election as determined by credible media two weeks following both the AP and Fox News projecting the opposite-party candidate to win the election AND neither the AP or Fox News having retracted their projection in that time.
4. A survey from the Morning Consult reveals that fewer than 30% of survey participants who are members of the losing party state that the election was "probably" or "definitely" free and fair in the most recent such survey following projections from both the AP and Fox News.
Resolution Criteria for the US-China war:
For the purposes of this question, a US-China war is defined as the US and China collectively suffering at least 1,000 battle-related deaths in conflicts with each other in a single calendar year, as reported by credible news, government, or multi-national sources. Deaths in battles fought between the US and an ally of China or between China and an ally of the US will not count towards positive resolution. If this does not occur before January 1, 2035, this question will resolve negatively.
We here define battle related deaths as defined by the Uppsala University Department of Peace and Conflict Studies.
Resolution will come from reputable news sources, from official federal or military announcements, or from multinational institutions like the UN or NATO.
This question resolves YES if either of the above conditions are met. It resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will Ray Kurzweil be proven right?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Ray Kurzweil is an author, computer scientist, inventor and futurist. He is best known for making what many consider to be extremely optimistic prediction about the future of technology that involve exponential growth leading up to technological singularity, which Kurzweil predicts will happen circa. 2045. A list of Kurzweil's predictions can be found here.
Will Ray Kurzweil be proven generally right in his predictions?
Note that the question refers to Kurzweil's predictions as of the time of the the writing of the question. Given that 'generally right' is hard to define, the question shall use consensus forming to create its own answer.
If the community prediction at the time of closing is > 80%, then the questions resolves positive.
If the community prediction at the time of closing is < 20%, then the questions resolves negative.
If the community prediction at the time of closing is ≥ 20% and ≤80%, then a member of Metaculus staff shall decide resolution.
To help reduce the vagueness of the question, Metaculus may, at its discretion, periodically survey the perceived correctness of Kurzweil's prediction, per a fixed methodology similar to that employed in this report, but with a modification to survey and weight by importance of the prediction.

Q.title: Will Metaculus exist in 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
A positive resolution does not require the site to still operate at metaculus.com in 2030, but it does require a degree of continuity with the current version of Metaculus so that no more than 1% of all predictions ever made may have been lost from players' point calculating process and no more than one percent of once opened questions may have been lost.
Due to the nature of this question the best point optimizing prediction would be 99%, no matter of the real probability of Metaculus existing in 2030, as a non-existent Metaculus cannot make you lose points. Still, players are urged to predict in good faith

P_or_Q.title: Will either Ray Kurzweil be proven generally right in his predictions or will Metaculus exist in 2030?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for Ray Kurzweil being proven right:
Ray Kurzweil is an author, computer scientist, inventor, and futurist known for his optimistic predictions about technology leading to a technological singularity around 2045. This question resolves YES if the community prediction at the time of closing is > 80%, NO if < 20%, and a Metaculus staff member will decide if between 20% and 80%. Metaculus may survey the perceived correctness of Kurzweil's predictions periodically.

Resolution Criteria for Metaculus existing in 2030:
A positive resolution requires a degree of continuity with the current version of Metaculus, ensuring no more than 1% of all predictions or opened questions have been lost. The question resolves YES if these conditions are met in 2030.

The question resolves YES if either Ray Kurzweil is proven generally right according to the specified criteria, or Metaculus exists in 2030 as defined. It resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will either Metaculus exist in 2030 or Ray Kurzweil be proven right in his predictions?
Q_or_P.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occur: (a) Metaculus exists in 2030 with no more than 1% of all predictions ever made lost from players' point calculating process and no more than one percent of once opened questions lost. (b) Ray Kurzweil is proven generally right in his predictions, where 'generally right' is defined by a community prediction at the time of closing being > 80% or a Metaculus staff decision if the prediction is between 20% and 80%. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will the research group that is responsible for developing the first AGI be part of a non-profit corporation?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the AI system that resolves the question Date first AGI is publicly known. was developed by a research group from a non-profit organization.
If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, the question resolves positively for both. For example, if OpenAI and UC Berkeley's CHAI had joined forces for the responsible project, this would count for both for-profit corporation and university.

Q.title: Will a Democrat win the 2024 US presidential election?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a candidate from the Democratic Party receives the most votes in the Electoral College in the 2024 US Presidential Election. It will resolve on the date Congress certifies the votes, or when Congress selects the President in the case a candidate does not receive a majority.

P_or_Q.title: Will either the research group responsible for developing the first AGI be part of a non-profit corporation or a Democrat win the 2024 US presidential election?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if either of the following occurs:
a.) The AI system that resolves the question 'Date first AGI is publicly known' was developed by a research group from a non-profit organization. If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, this would count for both for-profit corporation and university.
b.) A candidate from the Democratic Party receives the most votes in the Electoral College in the 2024 US Presidential Election. It will resolve on the date Congress certifies the votes, or when Congress selects the President in the case a candidate does not receive a majority.

Q_or_P.title: Will either a Democrat win the 2024 US presidential election or the research group that develops the first AGI be part of a non-profit corporation?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if either of the following occurs: 
1. A candidate from the Democratic Party receives the most votes in the Electoral College in the 2024 US Presidential Election. This will resolve on the date Congress certifies the votes, or when Congress selects the President in the case a candidate does not receive a majority.
2. The AI system that resolves the question 'Date first AGI is publicly known' was developed by a research group from a non-profit organization. If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, the question resolves positively for both. For example, if OpenAI and UC Berkeley's CHAI had joined forces for the responsible project, this would count for both for-profit corporation and university.
Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will there be an AI Sputnik moment before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
There is said to be an "AI Sputnik moment" if ANY of the following come true before 2050,
A major technology company (>50 billion dollar market cap, in 2021 US dollars, right before the announcement) announces the creation of an AI system. Upon the announcement, their stock price skyrockets by over 100% compared to its previous value within 7 days, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock price is likely a result of the AI development.
News of an AI development triggers the head of government of the top 2 nations by GDP nominal to give a public speech regarding the ramifications of this particular AI development, within two weeks of the initial news reports.
The Nasdaq Composite (which is currently heavily weighted towards companies in the information technology sector) rises over 30% in the course of a single week, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock prices is likely a result of the AI development.
The Google Trends monitor for artificial intelligence shows that interest in artificial intelligence rises by over 100% relative to of its previous value, compared to the week prior (using the resolution at 12 months, as currently displayed by the Google Trends widget). If Google Trends changes their functionality or methodology dramatically (as determined by Metaculus admins), then this condition can no longer trigger a positive resolution.
Practically all reliable media outlets are referring to an AI development as an AI Sputnik moment, as referring to the historical Sputnik 1 satellite
Fine Print
Google Trends index scores vary depending on the date and location from which a user checks the site. To reduce ambiguity, to trigger the Google Trends section of the resolution criteria:
At least two Metaculus administrators need to be able to see the >100% Google Trends increase, when checking from different locations.
The increase must remain >100% for at least four days to trigger a Yes resolution. For instance, if we first notice an increase of >100% on a Monday, we will check again on Friday. We will only resolve "Yes" if the reported increase for the weeks in question is >100% on both days we check, for both admins, and we have no evidence that it dropped below 100% at any point during those four days.

Q.title: If the first AGI is developed by a publicly traded company, will the company have performed at least 1.5x as well as the global equities market over the prior 12-2 months?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question defines Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) in the same way as this Metaculus question.
If the first AGI is developed by a publicly traded company, this question resolves according to the following methodology:
Let t be the date when the AGI is publicly known, as determined by the above Metaculus question. Let C be the company that developed the AGI.
Calculate the total return (including dividends) of C's stock over the period from 12 months prior to t to one month prior to t, inclusive.[1]
Over the same period, calculate the total return of the FTSE Global All Cap Index, or a similar index if FTSE no longer exists.
Calculate the ratio of C's total return over this period to the total return of FTSE. If the ratio is 1.5 or greater, then this question resolves affirmatively. Otherwise, it resolves negatively.
If the first AGI is not developed by a publicly traded company, this question resolves ambiguously.
[1] In the event that the market is closed on the start/end date, instead use the latest prior date on which the market is open. In the event that the date does not exist, use the latest prior date that exists. For example, if the AGI is developed on December 31, "one month prior" is considered to be November 30. If the market is closed on November 30, then use November 29 instead

P_or_Q.title: Will there be an AI Sputnik moment before 2050 or will a publicly traded company that develops the first AGI perform at least 1.5x as well as the global equities market over the prior 12-24 months?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolves YES if either of the following occur: 
1. An "AI Sputnik moment" occurs before 2050, defined by any of the following criteria: 
   - A major technology company (>50 billion dollar market cap, in 2021 US dollars, right before the announcement) announces the creation of an AI system, causing their stock price to skyrocket by over 100% within 7 days, with numerous credible media reports attributing this rise to the AI development. 
   - News of an AI development triggers the head of government of the top 2 nations by GDP nominal to give a public speech about the AI within two weeks of the initial news. 
   - The Nasdaq Composite rises over 30% in a week, with credible media reports linking this rise to the AI development. 
   - Google Trends shows a >100% increase in interest in artificial intelligence relative to the previous week, confirmed by at least two Metaculus administrators from different locations, remaining >100% for at least four days. 
2. The first AGI is developed by a publicly traded company and the company's total return (including dividends) from 12 months prior to the announcement to one month prior exceeds 1.5 times the total return of the FTSE Global All Cap Index or a similar index over the same period. 
Resolves NO if neither of these occur. If the first AGI is not developed by a publicly traded company, the second part resolves ambiguously.

Q_or_P.title: Will either the first AGI be developed by a publicly traded company that has performed at least 1.5x as well as the global equities market over the prior 12-2 months, or will there be an AI Sputnik moment before 2050?
Q_or_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for AGI Development by a Publicly Traded Company:
This question defines Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) in the same way as a specific Metaculus question. If the first AGI is developed by a publicly traded company, this question resolves according to the following methodology:
Let t be the date when the AGI is publicly known, as determined by the above Metaculus question. Let C be the company that developed the AGI.
Calculate the total return (including dividends) of C's stock over the period from 12 months prior to t to one month prior to t, inclusive. Over the same period, calculate the total return of the FTSE Global All Cap Index, or a similar index if FTSE no longer exists. Calculate the ratio of C's total return over this period to the total return of FTSE. If the ratio is 1.5 or greater, then this question resolves affirmatively. Otherwise, it resolves negatively. If the first AGI is not developed by a publicly traded company, this question resolves ambiguously.

Resolution Criteria for AI Sputnik Moment before 2050:
There is said to be an "AI Sputnik moment" if ANY of the following come true before 2050:
A major technology company (>50 billion dollar market cap, in 2021 US dollars, right before the announcement) announces the creation of an AI system. Upon the announcement, their stock price skyrockets by over 100% compared to its previous value within 7 days, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock price is likely a result of the AI development.
News of an AI development triggers the head of government of the top 2 nations by GDP nominal to give a public speech regarding the ramifications of this particular AI development, within two weeks of the initial news reports.
The Nasdaq Composite (which is currently heavily weighted towards companies in the information technology sector) rises over 30% in the course of a single week, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock prices is likely a result of the AI development.
The Google Trends monitor for artificial intelligence shows that interest in artificial intelligence rises by over 100% relative to of its previous value, compared to the week prior (using the resolution at 12 months, as currently displayed by the Google Trends widget). If Google Trends changes their functionality or methodology dramatically (as determined by Metaculus admins), then this condition can no longer trigger a positive resolution.
Practically all reliable media outlets are referring to an AI development as an AI Sputnik moment, as referring to the historical Sputnik 1 satellite.
Fine Print for Google Trends:
Google Trends index scores vary depending on the date and location from which a user checks the site. To reduce ambiguity, to trigger the Google Trends section of the resolution criteria:
At least two Metaculus administrators need to be able to see the >100% Google Trends increase, when checking from different locations.
The increase must remain >100% for at least four days to trigger a Yes resolution. For instance, if we first notice an increase of >100% on a Monday, we will check again on Friday. We will only resolve "Yes" if the reported increase for the weeks in question is >100% on both days we check, for both admins, and we have no evidence that it dropped below 100% at any point during those four days.

P.title: If >100 offensive nuclear detonations occur in a single conflict by 2030, will this cause a global temperature drop of ≥3°C?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the following two criteria are met:
There is a nuclear conflict with >100 offensive nuclear detonations by January 1, 2030
Average global temperature during the 3 years following the conflict is at least 3°C lower than the average global temperature during the 3 years prior to the conflict.
This question will resolve as ambiguous if there is no nuclear conflict with >100 offensive nuclear detonations by January 1, 2030.
Fine Print
This question will also resolve positively if the first nuclear conflict meeting the above-mentioned condition clearly causes more than this amount of decline in temperature but also causes sufficient civilizational collapse that there are no or extremely few remaining credible sources on any topic. We request that you forecast your true beliefs despite the fact that a Metaculus score seems unlikely to be tracked or cared about in that scenario, given that forecasts on this question may play a role in informing important decisions.
Detonations for testing purposes and peaceful nuclear explosions are not counted towards positive resolution. Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. If information is unclear, then resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins.
In a deliberate detonation, the attacking nation decides to launch one or more nuclear weapons either in response to a genuine nuclear attack or without believing that it is under nuclear attack. “In an inadvertent detonation, the attacking nation mistakenly concludes that it is under nuclear attack and launches one or more nuclear weapons in what it believes is a counterattack” (Barrett et al., 2013). “In an accidental or unauthorized launch or detonation, system safeguards or procedures to maintain control over nuclear weapons fail in such a way that a nuclear weapon or missile launches or explodes without direction from leaders” (Barrett et al., 2013).

Q.title: Will there be a 4 year interval in which world output doubles before 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution is by credible assessment of world GDP in constant US dollars (or other appropriately widely-accepted units).
This question will resolve positively if world output doubles in a period of 4 years or less before 2050. It resolves negatively otherwise, i.e. if the following related question resolves ambiguously:
[Will there be a complete 4 year interval in which world output doubles, before the first 1 year interval in which world output doubles?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/736/will-…
